column1: yathā bhavadbhiḥ pṛṣṭo'haṃ vadanārthe mahātmabhiḥ | purāvṛttaṃ mayā proktaṃ śivārcanavidheḥ phalam | śivena dattaṃ sālūpyaṃ na gṛhītaṃ mayā tadā || 77 || yācitaṃ ca mayā śaṃbhorvadanaṃ vānarasya ca | śivena kṛpayā dattaṃ mama kāruṇyaśālinā || 78 ||
column2: As he was told thus, he in his arrogance due to his might, asked me about my face in the same manner as I have been asked about my face by you noble-souled ones. The old story was recounted by me about the benefit of the holy rite of the worship of Śiva. “Sārūpya (having the same form as that of the lord) was granted by Śiva, but it was not accepted by me then. The face of a monkey was requested by me from Śaṃbhu. It was then granted to me kindly by Śiva who is by nature compassionate.

column1: nirābhimānino ye ca nirdabhā niṣparigrahāḥ | śaṃbhoḥ priyāste vijñeyā hyanye śivavabahiṣkṛtāḥ || 79 ||
column2: Those who are devoid of false prestige, those who are free from arrogance and those who have no property or possessions, should be known as favourites of Śaṃbhu. Others are excluded by Śiva.”

column1: tathāvadanmayā sārddhaṃ rāvaṇastapaso balāt | mayā ca yācitānyeva daśa vaktrāṇi dhīmatā || 80 ||
column2: 80-86a. Then Rāvaṇa said to me: “On the strength of my penance, I had been sensible enough to request for ten heads.”

column1: upahāsakaraṃ vākyaṃ paulastyasya tadā surāḥ | mayā tadā hi śapto'sau rāvaṇo lokarāvaṇaḥ || 81 ||
column2: At his derisive statement, Rāvaṇa who made the world scream, was cursed by me then:

column1: īdṛśānyeva vaktrāṇi yeṣāṃ vai saṃbhavaṃti hi | taiḥ sameto yadā ko'pi naravaryo mahātapāḥ | māṃ puraskṛtya sahasā haniṣyati na saṃśayaḥ || 82 ||
column2: “When an excellent man of great penance accompanied by those who have faces like this (monkey faces like mine) (comes to your city) keeping me at the head, he will undoubtedly kill you.”

column1: evaṃ śapto mayā brahmanrāvaṇo lokarāvaṇaḥ | arcitaṃ kevalaṃ liṃgaṃ vinā tena mahātmanā || 83 || pīṭhikārūpasaṃsthena vinā tena surottamāḥ | viṣṇunā hi mahābhāgāstasmātsarvaṃ vidhāsyati || 84 || devadevo mahādevo viṣṇurūpī maheśvaraḥ | sarve yūyaṃ prārthayaṃtu viṣṇuṃ sarvaguhāśayam || 85 ||
column2: Thus, O Brahmā, Rāvaṇa who made the world scream, was cursed by me. Only the Liṅga was worshipped by Ṛāvaṇa without the noble-souled Viṣṇu stationed in the form of the pedestal, O excellent Suras. Hence, O excessively fortunate ones, Maheśvara, Mahādeva, the lord of Devas, in the form of Viṣṇu will carry out everything. May all of you pray to Viṣṇu lying within the cavity of the heart of everyone. Therefore, I shall be at the head of all Devas.

column1: ahaṃ hi sarvadevānāṃ purovartī bhavāmyataḥ | te sarve naṃdino vākyaṃ śrutvā muditamānasāḥ | vaikuṃṭhamāgatā gīrbhirviṣṇuṃ stotuṃ pracakrire || 86 ||
column2: 86b. On hearing the words of Nandī, all of them became joyous in their minds. They came to Vaikuṇṭha and began to eulogize Viṣṇu by means of (good) words.

column1: devā ūcuḥ | namo bhagavate tubhyaṃ devadeva jagatpate | tvadādhāramidaṃ sarvaṃ jagadetaccarācaram || 87 ||
column2: Devas said: 87. Obeisance to you, the lord, O lord of Devas, O lord of the universe. This entire universe consisting of mobile and immobile beings has you for its basis and support.

column1: etalliṃgaṃ tvayā viṣṇo dhṛtaṃ vai piṇḍirūpiṇā | mahāviṣṇusvarūpeṇa ghātitau madhukaiṭabhau || 88 ||
column2: 88. This Liṅga has been held by you, O Viṣṇu, in the form of the Piṇḍī (globular pedestal). In the form of Mahāviṣṇu (the demons) Madhu and Kaiṭabha were killed by you.

column1: tathā kamaṭharūpeṇa dhṛto vai maṃdarācalaḥ | varāharūpamāsthāya hiraṇyākṣo hatastvayā || 89 ||
column2: 89. Similarly, in the form of a tortoise, the Mandara mountain was held up and supported by you (at the time of churning of ocean for nectar). Assuming the form of a boar, Hiraṇyākṣa was killed by you.

column1: hiraṇyakaśipurdaityo hato nṛharirūpiṇā | tvayā caiva balirbaddho daityo vāmanarūpiṇā || 90 ||
column2: 90. Hiraṇyakaśipu, the Daitya, was killed by you by assuming the form of Nṛhari (Man-lion). Bali, the Daitya, was held and bound by you in the form of Vāmana (Dwarf).

column1: bhṛgūṇāmanvaye bhūtvā kṛtavīryātmajo hataḥ | itopyasmānmahāviṣṇo tathaiva paripālaya || 91 ||
column2: 91. The son of Kṛtavīrya (Sahasrārjuna) was killed by you after taking birth in the family of Bhṛgus. Hereafter too, O great Viṣṇu, protect us in the same manner.

column1: rāvamasya bhayādasmāttrātuṃ bhūyorhasi tvaram || 92 ||
column2: 92. It behoves you to protect us instantaneously from the fear of Rāvaṇa.

column1: evaṃ saṃprārthito devairbhagavānbhūtabhāvanaḥ | uvāca ca surānsarvānvāsudevo jaganmayaḥ || 93 ||
column2: 93. On being entreated thus by Devas, the lord Vāsudeva, the sanctifier (the creator) of all living beings, who is immanent in the universe, said to all those Suras:

column1: he devāḥ śrūyatāṃ vākyaṃ prastāvasadṛśaṃ mahat | śailādiṃ ca puraskṛtya sarve yūyaṃ tvarānvitāḥ | avatārānprakurvantu vānarīṃ tanumāśritāḥ || 94 ||
column2: 94. “O Devas, let this important statement he heard. It is relevant to this occasion. With Śailādi (Nandin) as your head (leader), all of you immediately take incarnations in the form (bodies) of monkeys.

column1: ahaṃ hi mānuṣo bhūtvā hyajñānena samāvṛtaḥ | saṃbhaviṣyāmyayodhyāyaṃ gṛhe daśarathasya ca | brahmavidyāsahāyosmi bhavatāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 95 ||
column2: 95. I shall become a human being enveloped by Ajñāna (Ignorance). I shall be born in Ayodhyā in the abode of Daśaratha for the attainment of your objectives. I am having Brahmavidyā (the knowledge of Brahman) as my assistant.

column1: janakasya gṛhe sākṣādbrahmavidyā janiṣyati | bhakto hi rāvaṇaḥ sākṣācchivadhyānaparāyaṇaḥ || 96 ||
column2: 96. Brahmavidyā herself will be born in the abode of Janaka.[7] In fact, Rāvaṇa is (my) devotee as he is directly engaged in the meditation on Śiva.

column1: tapasā mahatā yukto brahmavidyāṃ yadecchati | tadā susādhyo bhavati puruṣo dharmanirjitaḥ || 97 ||
column2: 97. When a man endowed with great penance desires for Brahmavidyā, he can be easily managed and won over by means of virtue.”

column1: evaṃ saṃbhāṣya bhagavānviṣṇuḥ paramamaṅgalaḥ | vālī cendrāṃśasaṃbhūtaḥ sugrīvoṃ śumataḥ sutaḥ || 98 ||
column2: 98-100. After saying this, lord Viṣṇu, the highly auspicious one (vanished).

column1: tathā brahmāṃśasaṃbhūto jāmbavānnṛkṣakuñjaraḥ | śilādatanayo naṃdī śivasyānucaraḥ priyaḥ || 99 || yo vai caikādaśo rudro hanūmānsa mahākapiḥ | avatīrṇaḥ sahāyārthaṃ viṣṇoramitatejasaḥ || 100 ||
column2: Vālī was born of a part of Indra. Sugrīva was the son of the Sun. Jāmbavān, the leading Ṛkṣa (bear), was born of a part of Brahmā. Naṇḍī, the son of Śilāda, who was a favourite follower of Śiva, incarnated as the great monkey Hanūmān for rendering assistance to Viṣṇu of unmeasured splendour.

column1: maiṃdādayo'tha kapayaste sarve surasattamāḥ | evaṃ sarve suragaṇā avateruryathā tatham || 101 ||
column2: 101. The monkeys beginning with Mainda were all the excellent Suras. Thus, all Suras incarnated in a befitting manner.

column1: tathaiva viṣṇurutpannaḥ kauśalyānaṃdavarddhanaḥ | viśvasya ramaṇāccaiva rāma ityucyate budhaiḥ || 102 ||
column2: 102. Similarly, Viṣṇu was born as one who increased the delight of Kausalyā. He is called Rāma by learned men, because he pleased and gratified the entire universe.

column1: śeṣopi bhaktyā viṣṇośca tapasā'vātaradbhuvi || 103 ||
column2: 103. Due to his devotion to Viṣṇu, Śeṣa descended on the earth by means of the power of his penance.

column1: dordaṇḍāvapi viṣṇośca avatīrṇau pratāpinau | śatrughnabharatākhyau ca vikhyātau bhuvanatraye || 104 ||
column2: 104. The mighty arms of Viṣṇu incarnated as the valorous (Princes) named Śatrughṇa and Bharata well-renowned in the three worlds.

column1: mithilādhipateḥ kanyā yā uktā brahmavādibhiḥ | sā brahmavidyāvataratsurāṇāṃ kāryyasiddhaye | sītā jātā lāṃgalasya iyaṃ bhūmivikarṣaṇāt || 105 ||
column2: 105. She who was mentioned as Brahmavidyā by the expounders of the Vedas, incarnated as the daughter of the ruler of Mithilā for the fulfilment of the task of Suras. She was born from a furrow arising from the ploughing of the field with the ploughshare.[8]

column1: tasmātsīteti vikhyātā vidyā sānvīkṣikī tadā | mithilāyāṃ samutpannā maithitītyabhidhīyate || 106 ||
column2: 106. Hence, she became famous as Sītā. She was the Science of Metaphysics (personified). Since she was born in Mithilā, she is called Maithilī.

column1: janakasya kule jātā viśrutā janakātmajā | khyātā vedavatī pūrvaṃ brahmavidyāghanāśinī || 107 ||
column2: 107. She was born in the family of Janaka. Hence, she is well-known as Janakātmajā (Jānakī). This Brahmavidyā, the destroyer of sins, was formerly known as Vedavatī.

column1: sā dattā janakenaiva viṣṇave paramātmane || 108 || tayātha vidyayā sārddhaṃ devadevo jagatpatiḥ | ugre tapasi līno'sau viṣṇuḥ paramaduṣkaram || 109 || rāvaṇaṃ jetukāmo vai rāmo rājīvalocanaḥ | araṇyavāsamakaroddevānāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 110 ||
column2: 108-110. She was given by Janaka himself to Viṣṇu, the Supreme Soul. Along with her, the Vidyā (incarnated), Viṣṇu the greatest among the auspicious ones, the lord of Devas, the lord protector of the universe, became engaged in a severe penance. As he was desirous of defeating Rāvaṇa for the sake of the fulfilment of the task of Devas, the lotus-eyed Rāma stayed in forest (for the same purpose).

column1: śeṣāvatāro'pi mahāṃstapaḥ paramaduṣkaram | tatāpa parayā śaktyā devānāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 111 ||
column2: 111. Though the great incarnation of Śeṣa, (Lakṣmaṇa) performed an exceedingly difficult penance by means of his great Śakti (power), for the sake of the fulfilment of the task of Devas.

column1: śatrughno bharataścaiva tepatuḥ paramaṃ tapaḥ || 112 || tato'sau tapasā yuktaḥ sārddhaṃ tairdevatāgaṇaiḥ | sagaṇaṃ rāvaṇaṃ rāmaḥ ṣaḍbhirmāsairajīhanat | viṣṇunā ghātitaḥ śastraiḥ śivasārūpyamāptavān || 113 || sagamaḥ sa punaḥ sadyo baṃdhubhiḥ saha suvratāḥ || 114 ||
column2: 112-115. Śatrughna and Bharata too performed very great penance. Rāma who was thus endowed with the power of penance and was assisted and accompanied by those groups of Devas, killed Ṛāvaṇa along with his followers within six months. Killed by Viṣṇu by means of weapons, O sages of holy rites, he attained Sārūpya (having the same form as the god) of Śiva, along with his kinsmen and followers. By the grace of Śiva, he became (realized) the entire Dvaitādvaita (the essence of the philosophy of dualism and non-dualism).[9] Even the sages are deluded in the matter of discrimination between dualism and non-dualism. Men who are engaged in worshipping Śiva derive all those things.

column1: ye'rcayaṃti śivaṃ nityaṃ liṃgarūpiṇameva ca | striyo vāpyatha vā śūdrāḥ śvapacā hyaṃtyavāsinaḥ | taṃ śivaṃ prāpnuvaṃtyeva sarvaduḥkhopanāśanam || 116 ||
column2: 116. Those who continuously worship Śiva in the form of Liṅga, whether they be women or śūdras or cāṇḍālas or other low-caste people, do attain Śiva, the destroyer of all miseries.

column1: paśavo'pi paraṃ yātāḥ kiṃ punarmānuṣādayaḥ || 117 || ye dvijā brahmacaryeṇa tapaḥ paramamāsthitāḥ | varṣairanekairyajñānāṃ te'pi svargaparā bhavan || 118 ||
column2: 117-118. Even animals have attained the supreme lord. What then to say about human beings? The twice-born castes who have practised great penance observing the vow of celibacy and who have performed Yajñas for many years have attained (merely) Svarga (Heaven).

column1: jyotiṣṭomo vājapeyo hyatirātrādayo hyamī | yajñāḥ svargaṃ prayacchaṃti sattrīṇāṃ nātra saṃśayaḥ || 119 || tatra svargasukhaṃ bhuktvā puṇyakṣayakaraṃ mahat | puṇyakṣaye'pi yajvāno martyalokaṃ pataṃti vai || 120 || patitānāṃ ca saṃsāre daivādbuddhiḥ prajāyate | guṇatrayamayī viprāstāsutāstviha yoniṣu || 121 ||
column2: 119-123. There are many Yajñas[10] such as Jyotiṣṭoma, Vājapeya, Atirātra and so on. These Yajñas undoubtedly do bestow heavenly pleasures on those who perform them. After enjoying the heavenly pleasures, when their merits become exhausted, those sacrificers come back to the mortal world. Having descended to the world, they are born in the different species with their intellect of the nature of the three Guṇas of Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. Thus, many souls wander about in cycles of birth and death. By chance or as good luck would have it, some of them serve Śiva.

column1: śivadhyānaparāṇāṃ ca narāṇāṃ yatacetasām | māyānirasanaṃ sadyo bhaviṣyati na cānyathā || 124 ||
column2: 124. Instantaneous removal of Māyā takes place in the case of men who are engaged in regular meditation on Śiva and who have restrained their minds and not otherwise.

column1: māyānirasanātsadyo naśyatyeva guṇatrayam | yadā guṇatrayātīto bhavatīti sa muktibhāk || 125 ||
column2: 125. When Māyā is dispelled, the three Guṇas perish. Then a person transcends the three Guṇas and becomes liberated thereby.

column1: tasmālliṅgārcanaṃ bhāvyaṃ sarveṣāmapi dehinām | liṅgarūpī śivo bhūtvā trāyate saṃcarācaram || 126 ||
column2: 126-128. Hence, the worship of Liṅga should be thought of and pursued by all embodied beings. Śiva assumes the form of Liṅga and protects all mobile and immobile beings.

column1: purā bhavadbhiḥ pṛṣṭo'haṃ liṅgarūpī kathaṃ śivaḥ | tatsarvaṃ kathitaṃ viprā yāthātathyena saṃprati || 127 ||
column2: Formerly I have been asked by you about how Śiva assumed the form of Liṅga. Everything has now been truthfully spoken (by me), O Brāhmaṇas.

column1: kathaṃ garaṃ bhakṣitavāñchivo lokamaheśvaraḥ | tatsarvaṃ śrūyatāṃ viprā yatāvatkathayāmi vaḥ || 128 ||
column2: How Śiva, the great lord of the worlds, swallowed poison (Halāhala), may be listened to, O Brāhmaṇas, I shall recount it to you as it actually took place. FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES:

column1: lomaśa uvāca | ekadā tu sabhāmadhya āsthito devarāṭ svayam | lokapālaiḥ parivṛto devaiśca ṛṣibhistathā || 1 || apsarogaṇasaṃvīto gaṃdharvaiśca puraskṛtaḥ | upagīyamānavijayaḥ siddhavidyādharairapi || 2 ||
column2: 1-2. On one occasion Indra, the lord of Devas, was seated in the middle of the assembly surrounded by the guardians of the worlds, Devas and Sages. He was encircled by bevies of celestial damsels and was honoured by Gandharvas. Songs in praise of his conquest were being sung by Siddhas and Vidyādharas.

column1: tadā śiṣyaiḥ parivṛto devarājaguruḥ sudhīḥ | āgato'sau mahābhāgo bṛhaspati rudāradhīḥ || 3 ||
column2: 3. At that time Bṛhaspati who was the scholarly preceptor of the king of Devas and was of exalted fortune and liberal-minded, came there surrounded by his disciples.

column1: taṃ dṛṣṭvā sahasā devāḥ praṇemuḥ samupasthitāḥ | iṃdropi dadṛśe tatra prāptaṃ vācaspatiṃ tadā || 4 ||
column2: 4. On seeing him Devas who had been sitting there promptly bowed down to him. Indra too had seen Vācaspati’s (Bṛhaspati’s) arrival.

column1: novāca kiṃciddurmedhāvaco mānupuraḥsaram | nāhvānaṃ nāsanaṃ tasya na visarjanameva ca || 5 ||
column2: 5. But the vicious-minded lord did not utter a single word in his honour. No word of welcome, no offer of seat, no formal permission to leave was accorded to him.

column1: śakraṃ pramattaṃ jñātvātha madādrājyasya durmatim | tirodhānamanuprāpto bṛhaspatī ruṣānvitaḥ || 6 ||
column2: 6. Knowing that Śakra had become arrogant and evil-minded due to royal authority, Bṛhaspati became angry and he vanished.

column1: gate devagurau tasminvimanaskā'bhavansurāḥ | yakṣā nāgāḥ sagaṃdharvā ṛṣayo'pi tathā dvijāḥ || 7 ||
column2: 7. When the preceptor of Devas had departed, Suras became dejected. Yakṣas, Serpents, Gandharvas and sages also became depressed in mind, O Brāhmaṇas.

column1: gāṃdharvasyā vasāne tu labdhasaṃjño hariḥ surān | papraccha tvaritenavai kva gato hi mahātapāḥ || 8 ||
column2: 8. At the end of the music recital, Indra (as it were) regained consciousness. He asked Suras immediately, “Where has (the preceptor) of great penance gone?”

column1: tadaiva nāradenoktaḥ śakro devādhipastathā | tvayā kṛtā hyavajñā ca gurornastyatra saṃśayaḥ || 9 || guroravajñayā rājyaṃ gataṃ te balasūdana | tasmātkṣamāpanīyo'sau sarvabhāvena hi tvayā || 10 ||
column2: 9-10. At the very same time, Śakra, the lord of Devas, was informed by Nārada: “The preceptor has been insulted by you. There is no doubt about it. O slayer of Bala, your kingdom has gone due to the disrespect (shown by you) to the preceptor. Hence, by all means, you have to plead to him for forgiveness.”

column1: etacchrutvā vacastasya nāradasya mahātmanaḥ | āsanātsahasotthāya taiḥ sarvaiḥ parivāritaḥ | āgacchattvarayā śakro gurorgehamataṃdritaḥ || 11 ||
column2: 11. On hearing these words of the noble-souled Nārada, Śakra suddenly got up from his seat. Surrounded by all of them (Devas etc.), he hastened to the abode of his preceptor promptly (without any slackness).

column1: pṛṣṭvā tārāṃ praṇamyādau kva gato hi mahātapāḥ | na jānāmītyuvācedaṃ tārā śakraṃ nirīkṣatī || 12 ||
column2: 12. He bowed down to Tārā at the outset and asked her, “Where has (our preceptor) of great penance gone?” Tārā stared at Śakra and said, “I do not know.”

column1: tadā ciṃtānvito bhūtvā śakraḥ svagṛhamāvrajat | etasminnaṃtare svarge hyaniṣṭāndbhutāni ca || 13 || abhavansarvaduḥkhārthe śakrasya ca mahātmanaḥ | pātālasthena balinā jñātaṃ śakrasya ceṣṭitam || 14 ||
column2: 13-15. Thereupon, Śakra became worried and returned to his own house. In the meantime, there appeared mysterious ill-omens in heaven, causing misery to everyone including the noble-minded Śakra himself.

column1: yayau daityaiḥ parivṛtaḥ pātālādamarāvatīm | tadā yuddhamatīvāsīddevānāṃ dānavaiḥ saha || 15 ||
column2: All the activities of Śakra were known to Bali who was stationed in the nether worlds. Surrounded by Daityas, he went from Pātāla to Amarāvatī. Thereupon a great fight ensued between Devas and Dānavas.

column1: devāḥ parājitā daityai rājyaṃ śakrasya tatkṣaṇāt | saṃprāptaṃ sakalaṃ tasya mūḍhasya ca durātmanaḥ || 16 || nītaṃ sarvaprayatnena pātālaṃ tvaritaṃ gatāḥ | śukraprasādātte sarve tathā vijayino'bhavan || 17 || śakro'pi niḥśriko jāto devaistyaktastato bhṛśam | devī tirodhānagatā babhūva kamalekṣaṇā || 18 ||
column2: 16-18. Devas were defeated by Daityas. Instantaneously the whole of the kingdom of Śakra, the deluded and evil-minded one, was conquered by them and everything (belonging to Śakra) was quickly carried to Pātāla. It was by the grace of Śukra that all of them became victorious. Śakra became bereft of glory and splendour. So he was utterly abandoned by Devas. The goddess (of fortune) with lotus-like eyes vanished.

column1: airāvato mahānāgastathaivoccaiḥśravā hayaḥ | evamādīni ratnāni anekāni bahūnyapi | nītāni sahasā daityairlobhādasādhuvṛttibhiḥ || 19 ||
column2: 19. The great elephant Airāvata, the horse Uccaiḥśravas and many other precious things and jewels were taken away immediately by Daityas of evil behaviour due to greed.

column1: puṇyabhāṃji ca tānyeva patitāni ca sāgare | tadā sa vismayāviṣṭo balirāha guruṃ prati || 20 ||
column2: 20. The good ones among them fell into the ocean. Bali who was surprised at this, remarked to his preceptor:

column1: devānnirjitya cāsmābhirānītāni bahūni ca | ratnāni tu samudre'tha patitāni tadadbhutam || 21 ||
column2: 21. “It is mysterious that many jewels brought by us after defeating Devas have fallen into the ocean.”

column1: balestadvacanaṃ śrutvā uśanā pratyuvāca tam | aśvamedhaśatenaiva surarājyaṃ bhaviṣyati | dīkṣitasya na saṃdehastasmādbhokta sa eva ca || 22 || aśvamedhaṃ vinā kiṃcitsvargaṃ bhoktaṃ na pāryate || 23 ||
column2: 22-23. On hearing the words of Bali, Uśanas (i.e. Śukra) replied to him: “One can attain the heavenly kingdom only through performance of a hundred horse-sacrifices. There is no doubt about it that it will be acquired by one who is initiated in it. Hence, the enjoyer is also he himself. Without performing a horse-sacrifice, heavenly pleasures cannot at all be enjoyed.”

column1: gurorvacanamājñāya tūṣṇīṃbhūto balistataḥ | babhūva devaiḥ sārddhaṃ ca yathocitamakārayat || 24 ||
column2: 24. Understanding the utterance of his preceptor, Bali became quite silent. What was proper and befitting was carried out through and along with Devas.

column1: indropi śocyatāṃ prāpto jagāma parameṣṭhinam | vijñāpayāmāsa tathā sarvaṃ rājyabhayādikam || 25 ||
column2: 25. Indra too, on attaining a miserable plight, went to Parameṣṭhin (Brahmā) and informed him of everything, such as the danger to his kingdom and other things.

column1: śakrasya vacanaṃ śrutvā parameṣṭhī uvāca ha || 26 || saṃmilitvā surānsarvāṃstvayā sākaṃ tvarānvitāḥ | ārādhanārthaṃ gacchāmo viṣṇuṃ sarveśvareśvaram || 27 ||
column2: 26-28. On hearing the words of Śakra, Parameṣṭhī said: “We shall gather together all the Suras and go immediately along with you to Viṣṇu, the lord of all lords, in order to propitiate him.”

column1: tatheti gatvā te sarve śakrādyā lokapālakāḥ | brahmāṇaṃ ca puraskṛtya taṭaṃ kṣīrārṇavasya ca | prāpyopaviśya te sarve hariṃ stotuṃ pracakramuḥ || 28 ||
column2: Saying “So be it” all those guardians of the worlds beginning with Śakra went to the shore of the Milk Ocean with Brahmā at their head. After sitting there all of them began to eulogize Hari. Brahmā said:

column1: brahmovāca | devadeva jagānnātha surāsuranamaskṛta | puṇyaślokāvyayānaṃta paramātmannamo'stu te || 29 ||
column2: 29-31. O lord of the universe, O lord of Devas bowed down to by Suras as well as Asuras, obeisance to you, O great Ātman, of auspicious reputation, O infinite one, O immutable one, free from decay.

column1: yajño'si yajñarūpo'si yajñāṃgo'si ramāpate | tato'dya kṛpayā viṣṇo devānāṃ varado bhava || 30 ||
column2: You yourself are Yajña. You are of the form of Yajña, O consort of Lakṣmī. Hence, be the bestower of boons unto the Devas.

column1: guroravajñayā cādya bhraṣṭarājyaḥ śatakratuḥ | jātaḥ surarṣibhiḥ sākaṃ tasmādenaṃ samuddhara || 31 ||
column2: By insulting his preceptor, Indra has lost (everything) from his kingdom along with the celestial sages. Hence redeem him.

column1: śrībhagavānuvāca | dukokalajñayā sarvaṃ nasyatīti kimadbhutam | ye pāpino hyadharmiṣṭhāḥ kevalaṃ viṣayātmakāḥ | pitarau niṃditau yaiśca nirdaivātvena saṃśayaḥ || 32 ||
column2: The Lord said: 32. There is no wonder in the fact that everything perishes by insulting the preceptor. Those who are sinners, who are completely engaged in evil activities, who indulge only in sensual pleasures and by whom parents are censured, are undoubtedly godless ones.

column1: anena yatkṛtaṃ brahmansadyastatphalamāgatam | karmaṇā cāsya śakrasya sarveṣāṃ saṃkaṭāgamaḥ || 33 ||
column2: 33. Immediately he has acquired the fruit, O Brahmā, of what he has committed. Difficulty and misfortune have befallen all due to the act of this Śakra.

column1: viparīto yadā kālaḥ puruṣasya bhavettadā | bhūtamaitrīṃ prakurvaṃti sarvakāryārthasiddhaye || 34 ||
column2: 34. When a person faces adverse circumstances, they say that, he must be friendly with all living beings in order to achieve all his purposes.

column1: tena vai kāraṇeneṃdra madīyaṃ vacanaṃ kuru | kāryahetostvayā kāryo daityaiḥ saha samāgamaḥ || 35 ||
column2: 35. For that reason, Indra, do as I suggest. For the realization of your purpose, alliance should be formed by you with Daityas.

column1: evaṃ bhagavatādiṣṭaḥ śakraḥ paramabuddhimān | amarāvatīṃ yayau hitvā sutalaṃ daivataiḥ saha || 36 ||
column2: 36. On being commanded by the lord, the highly intelligent Śakra left Amarāvatī and went to Sutala along with Devas.

column1: indraṃ samāgataṃ śrutvā iṃdraseno ruṣānvitaḥ | babhūva saha sainyena haṃtukāmaḥ puraṃdaram || 37 ||
column2: 37. On seeing that Indra had come, Indrasena became furious. Along with his army, he was desirous of killing Indra.

column1: nāradena tadā daityā baliśca balināṃ varaḥ | nivāritastadvadhācca vākyairuccāvacaistathā || 38 ||
column2: 38. Then by means of different types of (consoling) words, Daityas and Bali, the most excellent one among strong persons, were prevented from killing him by Nārada.

column1: ṛṣestasyaiva vacanāttyaktamanyurbalistadā | babhūva saha sainyena āgato hi śatakratuḥ || 39 || indrasenena dṛṣṭo'sau lokapālaiḥ samāvṛtaḥ | uvāca tvarayā yuktaḥ prahasanniva daityarāṭ || 40 ||
column2: 39-40. At the instance of that same sage, Bali controlled (abandoned) his anger. Indra then came in along with his array. He was seen by Indrasena surrounded by the guardians of the worlds. The king of Daityas hastened to tell him laughingly:

column1: kasmādihāgataḥ śakra sutalaṃ prati kathyatām | tasyaitadvacanaṃ śrutvā smayamāna uvācatam || 41 ||
column2: 41. “Wherefore have you come here to Sutala, O Śakra? Let it be mentioned.” On hearing these words, he said smilingly:

column1: vayaṃ kaśyapadāyādā yūyaṃ sarve tathaiva ca | yathā vayaṃ tathā yūyaṃ vigraho hi nirarthakaḥ || 42 ||
column2: 42. “We are the descendants of Kaśyapa. All of you are also so. Just as we are, so also you are. Clash and quarrel is meaningless.

column1: mama rājyaṃ kṣaṇenaiva nītaṃ daivavaśāttavayā | tathā hyetāni tānyena ratnāni subahūnyapi | gatāni tatkṣaṇādeva yatnānītāni vai tvayā || 43 ||
column2: 43. As fate would have it, my kingdom was seized by you instantaneously. So also many gems were taken away by you. Though brought with very great effort, they too have gone.

column1: tasmādvimarśaḥ kartavyaḥ puruṣeṇa vipaścitā | vimarśajjāyate jñānaṃ jñānānmokṣo bhaviṣyati || 44 ||
column2: 44. Hence a learned person must deliberate and ponder. One gets knowledge by means of deliberation and liberation originates from knowledge.

column1: kiṃ tu me bata uktena jāne na ca tavāgrataḥ | śaraṇārthī hyahaṃ prāptaḥ suraiḥ saha tavāṃtikam || 45 ||
column2: 45. But alas! of what avail is my utterance in front of you? I do not know. I have approached you along with Suras as a person seeking refuge.”

column1: etacchrutvā tu śakrasya vākyaṃ vākyavidāṃ varaḥ | prahasyovāca matimāñchakraṃ prati vidāṃ varaḥ || 46 ||
column2: 46. On hearing these words of Śakra, the intelligent (Daitya), the most excellent one among knowers (learned), the most excellent one among those who know what to say, said laughingly to Śakra:

column1: tvamāgatosi deveṃdra kimarthaṃ tanna vedmayaham || 47 ||
column2: 47. “For what purpose, O Devendra, you have come, I do not know.”

column1: śakrastadvacanaṃ śrutvā hyaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇaḥ | kiṃcinnovāca tatrainaṃ nārado vākyamabravīt || 48 ||
column2: 48. On hearing those words, Śakra’s eyes became filled with tears. He did not say anything. Nārada spoke to him the following words:

column1: bale tvaṃ kiṃ na jānāsi kāryākāryavicāraṇām | dharmo hi mahatāmeṣa śaraṇāgatapālanam || 49 ||
column2: 49. “O Bali, don’t you know the difference between right and wrong activities? This is the virtue of great men. They protect those who seek refuge in them.

column1: śaraṇāgataṃ ca vipraṃ ca rogiṇaṃ vṛddhameva ca | yaetānna ca rakṣaṃti te vai brahmahaṇo narāḥ || 50 ||
column2: 50. Those who do not protect the one who seeks refuge, a Brāhmaṇa, a sick man and an old man, are (really) slaughterers of Brāhmaṇas.

column1: śaraṇāgataśabdena āgatastava sannidhau | saṃrakṣaṇāya yogyaśca tvayā nāstyatra saṃśayaḥ | evamukto nāradena tadā daityapatiḥ svayam || 51 || vimṛśya parayā buddhyā kāryākāryavicāraṇām | śakraṃ prapūjayāmāsa bahumānapuraḥsaram | lokapālaiḥ sametaṃ ca tathā suragaṇaiḥ saha || 52 ||
column2: 51-52. He has come to your presence with words asking for refuge. He is worthy of being protected by you. There is no doubt in this matter.” On being told thus by Nārada, the lord of Daityas himself pondered over everything with great understanding regarding what was right and what was wrong. With great respect, he honoured Śakra along with the guardians of the worlds as well as the groups of Devas.

column1: pratyayārthaṃ ca sattvāni hyanekāni vratāni vai | balipratyayabhūtāni sa cakāraḥ puraṃdaraḥ || 53 ||
column2: 53. For the sake of credence, Puranadara performed many good holy observances of the Sāttvika quality which created confidence in Bali.

column1: evaṃ sa samayaṃ kṛtvā śakraḥ svārthaparāyaṇaḥ | balinā saha cāvāsīdarthaśāstraparo mahān || 54 ||
column2: 54. Thus Śakra entered into an agreement with Bali in order to further his selfish ends. That great lord stayed with Bali solely devoting himself to the (precepts in the) science of political economy.

column1: evaṃ nivasatastasya sutale'pi śatakratoḥ | vatsarā bahavo hyāsaṃstadā buddhimakalpayat | saṃsmṛtya vacanaṃ viṣṇorvimṛśya ca punaḥpunaḥ || 55 ||
column2: 55. Thus Indra passed many years living in Sutala. Remembering the words of Viṣṇu and pondering over them again and again, he thought of a plan.

column1: ekadā tu sabhāmadhya āsīno devarāṭsvayam | uvāca prahasanvākyaṃ balimuddiśya nītimān || 56 ||
column2: 56. Once the king of Devas himself was sitting in the middle of the assembly (of Bali). Conversant with the right policy, he spoke laughingly these words to Bali:

column1: prāptavyāni tvayā vīra asmākaṃ ca tvayā bale | gajādīni bahūnyeva ratnāni vividhāni ca || 57 || gatāni tatkṣaṇādeva sāgare patitāni vai | prayatno hi prakartavyo hyasmābhistvayānvitaiḥ || 58 ||
column2: 57-58. “Many gems and jewels, elephants etc. have dropped into the ocean, while you were bringing them here. They belonged to us then. They should be recovered from the ocean by you as well as by us, O heroic one.

column1: teṣāṃ coddharaṇe daitya ratnānāmiha sāgarāt | tarhi nirmathanaṃ kāryaṃ bhavatā kāryasiddhaye || 59 ||
column2: 59. We must hurry up in exerting ourselves to recover those jewels from the ocean. Hence, it must be churned by you for the purpose of achieving the desired result.”

column1: baliḥ pravartitastena śakreṇa surasūdanaḥ | uvāca śakraṃ tvaritaḥ kenedaṃ mathanaṃ bhavet || 60 ||
column2: 60. Induced thus by Śakra, Bali, the slayer of Suras, spoke to Śakra immediately, “By whom and with what should the churning be done?”

column1: tadā nabhogatā vāṇī meghagaṃbhīraniḥsvanā | uvāca devā daityāśca maṃthadhvaṃ kṣīrasāgaram || 61 || bhavatāṃ balavṛddhiśca bhaviṣyati na saṃśayaḥ || 62 || maṃdaraṃ caiva maṃthānaṃ rajjuṃ kuruta vāsukim | paścāddevāśca daityāśca melayitvā vimathyatām || 63 ||
column2: 61-63. Then an ethereal voice with the majestic rumbling sound of cloud said: “O Devas, O Daityas, do churn the Ocean of Milk. There is no doubt about this that your strength will increase. Make the Mandara mountain the churning rod and Vāsuki the requisite rope. Afterwards, O Devas and Daityas, join together and let the ocean be churned.”

column1: nabhogatāṃ ca tāṃ vāṇīṃ niśamyātha tadāḥsurāḥ | daityaiḥ sārddhaṃ tataḥ sarva udyamaṃ cakrurudyatāḥ || 64 ||
column2: 64. On hearing the words of that ethereal voice, all Suras exerted themselves along with Daityas.

column1: pātālānnirgatāḥ sarve tadā te'tha surāsurāḥ | ājagmuratulaṃ sarve maṃdaraṃ parvatottamam || 65 ||
column2: 65. Those Suras and Asuras came out of Pātāla. They all came to the matchless, excellent mountain Mandara.

column1: daityāśca koṭisaṃkhyākāstathā devā na saṃśayaḥ | udyuktāḥ sahasā prā'yurmaṃdaraṃ kanakaprabham || 66 ||
column2: 66. Daityas were ten million in number. So also were Devas undoubtedly. Preparing themselves, they came to Mandara having golden lustre.

column1: saratnaṃ vartulākāraṃ sthūlaṃ caiva mahāprabham | anekaratnasaṃvītaṃ nānādrumaniṣevitam || 67 || caṃdanaiḥ pārijātaiśca nāgapunnāgacaṃpakaiḥ | nānāmṛgagaṇākīrṇaṃ siṃhaśārdūlasevitam || 68 ||
column2: 67-68. It abounded in gems and precious stones. It was globular in shape. It was very big and exceedingly lustrous. Many gems were (lying scattered) all round. It had many trees such as sandal tree, Pārijāta, Nāga, Punnāga and Caṃpaka. It was full of various kinds of animals and deer, lions and tigers.

column1: mahāśailaṃ dṛṣṭvā te surasattamāḥ | ūcuḥ prāṃjalayaḥ sarve tadā te surasattamāḥ || 69 ||
column2: 69. On seeing such a great mountain, all the excellent Suras, joined their palms in reverence and said: Devas said:

column1: devā ūcuḥ | adre surā vayaṃ sarve vijñaptumiha cāgatāḥ | tacchṛṇuṣva mahāśaila pareṣāmupakārakaḥ || 70 ||
column2: 70. O mountain, all of us, the Suras have come here to submit to you. "Listen to it, O great mountain, the helper of others.

column1: evamuktastadā śailo davairdaityaiḥ sa maṃdaraḥ | uvāca niḥsṛto bhūtvā paraṃ vigrahavānvacaḥ || 71 || tena rūpeṇa rūpī sa parvato maṃdarācalaḥ | kimarthamāgatāḥ sarve matsamīpaṃ taducyatām || 72 ||
column2: 71-72. On being requested thus by Devas and Daityas then, the mountain Mandara came out in an embodied form and ia that form the mountain Mandara said: “What for have all of you come to me? Let that be mentioned.”

column1: tadā baliruvācedaṃ prastāvasadṛśaṃ vacaḥ | iṃdropi tvarayā yukto babhāṣe sūnṛtaṃ vacaḥ || 73 ||
column2: 73. Then Bali said these words befitting the occasion. Indra too hurriedly spoke these courteous and sincere words:

column1: asmābhiḥ saha kāryārthe bhava tvaṃ maṃdarācala | amṛtotpādanārthe tvaṃ maṃthānaṃ bhava suvrata || 74 ||
column2: 74. “O mountain Mandara, you cooperate with us in a great undertaking. O observer of holy vows, you should be the churning rod for the production of nectar.”

column1: tatheti matvā tadvākyaṃ devānāṃ kāryasiddhaye | ūce devāsurāṃścedamindraṃ prati viśeṣataḥ || 75 ||
column2: 75. Saying “So be it” and honouring their words, because it was for the accomplishment of the task of Devas, he spoke these words to Devas and Asuras and particularly to Indra:

column1: cheditau ca tvayā pakṣau vajreṇa śataparvaṇā | gaṃtuṃ kathaṃ samartho'haṃ bhavatāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 76 ||
column2: 76. “My wings have been cut (by you) with the thunderbolt of hundred spikes. How is it possible for me to go for realizing your purpose?”

column1: tadā devāsurāḥ sarve stūyamānā mahācalam | utpāṭayeyuratulaṃ maṃdaraṃ ca tatodbhutam || 77 ||
column2: 77. Then all Devas and Asuras praised the mountain. They then uprooted that incomparable and wonderful Mandara mountain.

column1: kṣīrārṇavaṃ netukāmā hyaśaktāste tato'bhavan | parvataḥ patitaḥ sadyo devadaityopari dhruvam || 78 ||
column2: 78. But, though they were desirous of taking it to the Milky Ocean, they proved incapable of doing it. The mountain fell on Devas and Daityas.

column1: kecidbhagnā mṛtāḥ kecitkecinmūrchāparā bhavan | parīvādaratāḥ kecitkecitkleśatvamāgatāḥ || 79 ||
column2: 79. Some were crushed. Softie died. Some fell into a swoon. Some of them began to blame and censure and some suffered great pain.

column1: ेvaṃ bhagnodyamā jātā asurāḥsuradānavāḥ | cetanāṃ paramāṃ prāptāstuṣṭuvurjagadīśvaram || 80 ||
column2: 80. Thus, Asuras, Suras and Dānavas failed in their attempt. When they regained consciousness, they eulogized the Lord of the universe:

column1: rakṣarakṣa mahāviṣṇo śaraṇāgatavatsala | tvayā tatamidaṃ sarvaṃ jaṃgamājaṃgamaṃ ca yat || 81 ||
column2: 81. “Save us, save us, O great Viṣṇu, O lord compassionate to those who seek refuge. The entire world, mobile as well as immobile, is pervaded by you.”

column1: devānāṃ kāryasiddhyarthaṃ prādurbhūto haristadā | tāndṛṣṭvā sahasā viṣṇurgaruḍopari saṃsthitaḥ || 82 || līlayā parvataśreṣṭhamuttabhyāropayatkṣaṇāt | garutmati tadā devaḥ sarveṣāmabhayaṃ dadau || 83 ||
column2: 82-83. Then Hari appeared before them for the accomplishment of the purpose of Devas. Viṣṇu who was seated on Garuḍa, saw them and suddenly and sportingly lifted up the excellent mountain and placed it on Garuḍa.[1] Then, the lord granted all of them protection from fear.

column1: tata utthāya tāndevānkṣīrosyottaraṃ taṭam | nītvā taṃ parvataṃ vṛddhaṃ nikṣipyāpsu tato yayau || 84 ||
column2: 84. Rising from there (and taking leave of) those Devas, he took the old mountain to the northern shore of the Ocean of Milk. After placing it in the waters, he went away from that place.

column1: tadā sarve suragaṇāḥ svāgatya asuraiḥ saha | vāsukiṃ ca samādāya cakrire samayaṃca tam || 85 ||
column2: 85. Then all those groups of Suras arrived there along with Asuras, taking Vāsuki with them. Then they made the agreement.

column1: maṃthānaṃ maṃdaraṃ caiva vāsukiṃ rajjumeva ca | kṛtvā surā'surāḥ sarve mamaṃthuḥ śrīrasāgaram || 86 ||
column2: 86. After making Mandara the churning rod and Vāsuki the rope, all of them, Suras and Asuras, churned the Ocean of Milk.

column1: kṣīrābdhermathyamānasya parvato hi rasātalam | gataḥ sa tatkṣaṇādeva kūrmo bhūtvā ramāpatiḥ | uddhṛtastatkṣaṇādeva tadadbhutamivābhavat || 87 ||
column2: 87. As the Ocean of Milk was being churned, the mountain sank deep into Rasātala. At that very instant, the Lord of Ramā, Viṣṇu, became a tortoise and lifted it up. That was something really marvellous.

column1: bhrāmyamāṇastataḥ śailo noditaḥ suradānavaiḥ | bhramamāṇo nirādhāro bodhaśceva guruṃ vinā || 88 ||
column2: 88. When the mountain rotated, it was further pulled and pushed by Suras and Dānavas. Now it rotated without any basis, like the understanding without a preceptor.

column1: paramātmā tadā viṣṇurādhāro maṃdarasya ca | dorbhiścaturbhiḥ saṃgṛhya mamaṃthābdhiṃ sukhāvaham || 89 ||
column2: 89. Viṣṇu, the supreme soul, then became the basic support of the Mandara mountain. With his four hands he gathered it up and churned pleasantly.

column1: tadā surāsurāḥ sarve mamaṃthuḥ kṣīrasāgaram | ekībhūtvā balenaivamatimātraṃ balotkaṭāḥ || 90 ||
column2: 90. Then all Suras and Asuras churned the Ocean of Milk after uniting together. Very powerful themselves, by uniting together, they became all the more powerful.

column1: pṛṣṭhakaṃṭhorujānvaṃtaḥ kamaṭhasya mahātmanaḥ | tathāsau parvataśreṣṭho vajrasāramayo dṛḍhaḥ | ubhayorgharṣaṇādeva vaḍavāgniḥ samutthitaḥ || 91 ||
column2: 91. The excellent mountain had adamantine strength. It rolled on the back, neck, thighs and the space between the knees of the noble-souled tortoise. Due to the friction of these two, submarine fire was generated.

column1: halāhalaṃ ca saṃjātaṃ tadṝṣṭvā nāradena hi | tato devānuvācedaṃ devarṣiramitadyutiḥ || 92 ||
column2: 92. The Halāhala poison too emerged and it was seen by Nārada. Thereafter, the celestial sage of unmeasured splendour spoke these words:

column1: na kāryaṃ mathanaṃ cābdherbhavadbhiradhunā'khilaiḥ | prārthayadhvaṃ śivaṃ devāḥ sarve dakṣasya yājanam | tadvismṛtiṃ ca voyātaṃ vīrabhadreṇa yatkṛtam || 93 ||
column2: 93-94, “The churning of the ocean should not be carried on by you all now. O Devas, all of you pray to Śiva.[2] Have you forgotten the sacrifice of Dakṣa and what Vīrabhadra did there?

column1: tasmācchivaḥ smaryatāṃ cāśu devāḥ paraḥ parāṇāmapi vā paraśca | parātparaḥ paramānaṃdarūpo yogidhyeyo niṣprapaṃco hyarūpaḥ || 94 ||
column2: Hence, let Śiva be immediately remembered, O Devas. He is greater than the greatest; he is beyond the greatest. He is the embodiment of supreme bliss. He is worthy of being meditated upon by Yogins; he has no form. (As a matter of fact) however, he is formless and unmanifest (or without diversity).”

column1: te mathyamānāstvaritā devāḥ svātmārthasādhakāḥ | abhilāṣaparāḥ sarve na śrṛṇvaṃti yato jaḍāḥ || 95 ||
column2: 95. Devas were eager to achieve their purpose. Therefore, they hurriedly went on churning the ocean. All those who are overwhelmed by desires do not listen (to the advice of others), because they become irrational and stupid.

column1: upadeśaiśca bahubhirnopadeśyāḥ kadācana | te rāgadveṣasaṃghātāḥ sarve śivaparāṅmukhāḥ || 96 ||
column2: 96. They should not be given many pieces of advice and instructions. They are subject to Rāga (desire) and Dveṣa (hatred). All of them are averse to Śiva.

column1: kevalodyamasaṃvītā mamaṃthuḥ kṣīrasāgaram | atinirmathanājjātaṃ kṣīrābdheścahalāhalam || 97 ||
column2: 97. With their sheer continuous exertion, they churned the Ocean of Milk. Due to excessive churning, the poison called Halāhala was generated from the Ocean of Milk.[3]

column1: trailokyadahane prauḍhaṃ prāptaṃ haṃtuṃ divaukasaḥ | ata ūrdhvaṃ diśaḥ sarvā vyāptaṃ kṛtsnaṃ nabhastalam | grasituṃ sarvabhūtānāṃ kālakūṭaṃ samabhyayāt || 98 ||
column2: 98. It was strong enough to burn down the three worlds. It came up to kill the heaven-dwellers. It went up still further and spread to all quarters. The entire sky was pervaded by it. The Kālakūṭa poison advanced to consume all the living beings.

column1: dṛṣṭvā bṛhaṃtaṃ svakarasthamojasā taṃ sarparājaṃ saha parvatena | tatraiva hitvāpayayustadānīṃ palāyamānā hyasuraiḥ sametāḥ || 99 ||
column2: 99. They observed the huge king of serpents grasped by their own hands. They left him there along with the mountain and then went (immediately) away. They fled along with Asuras.

column1: tathaiva sarva ṛṣayo bhṛgvādyāḥ śataśāmyati | dakṣasya yajanaṃ tena yathā jātaṃ tathābhavat || 100 ||
column2: 100. So also the sages beginning with Bhṛgu, sages in hundreds (fled in all directions). It was like what happened at the sacrifice of Dakṣa.

column1: satyalokaṃ gatāḥ sarve bhuguṇā noditā bhṛśam | vedavākyaiśca vividhaiḥ kālakūṭaṃ śataśastataḥ | devā nāstyatra saṃdehaḥ satyaṃ satyaṃ vadāmi vaḥ || 101 ||
column2: 101. Earnestly urged by Bhṛgu, all of them went to Satyaloka: “This poison Kālakūṭa will be quelled by means of various Vedic Sentences. O Devas, there is no doubt in this matter. It is true; I am speaking the truth unto you.”

column1: bhṛguṇoktaṃ vacaḥ śrutvā kālakūṭaviṣārdditāḥ | satyalokaṃ samāsādya brahmāṇaṃ śaraṇaṃ yayuḥ || 102 ||
column2: 102. On hearing these words uttered by Bhṛgu, all of them distressed by the poison Kālakūṭa went to Satyaloka and sought refuge in Brahmā.

column1: tadā jājvalyamānaṃ vai kālakūṭaṃ prabhojjavalam | dṛṣṭvā brahmātha tāndṛṣṭvā hyakarmajñānasurāsurān | teṣāṃ śapitumārebhe nāradena nivāritaḥ || 103 ||
column2: 103. Brahmā saw the blazing Kālakūṭa with sparkling lustre. He found that Suras and Asuras were ignorant of their duties. He was about to curse them, but he was prevented by Nārada.

column1: brahmovāca | akāryaṃ kiṃ kṛtaṃ devāḥ kasmātkṣobhoyamudyataḥ | īśvarasya ca jāto'dya nānyathā mama bhāṣitam || 104 ||
column2: Brahmā said: 104. O Devas, what a wrong thing has been committed by you? Why has this explosive thing cropped up? It is Īśvara’s anger. My speech cannot be otherwise.

column1: tato devaiḥ parivṛto vedopaniṣadaistathā | nānāgamaiḥ parivṛtaḥ kālakūṭabhayādyayau || 105 ||
column2: 105. Thereupon, surrounded by Devas, the Vedas, the Upāniṣads and the different kinds of Āgamas, he proceeded ahead out of fear of the Kālakūṭa.

column1: tataściṃtānvitā devā idamūcuḥ parasparam | avidyākāmasaṃvītāḥ kuryāmaḥ śaṃkaraṃ ca kam || 106 ||
column2: 106. Then, Devas who were worried said to to one another, “We are enveloped in Avidyā (nescience) and lust. How can we do anything to Śaṅkara?”

column1: brahmāṇaṃ ca puraskṛtya tadā devāstvarānvitāḥ | vaikuṇṭhamāvrajansarve kālakūṭa bhayārdditāḥ || 107 ||
column2: 107. Then Devas kept Brahmā at their head and hurriedly went to Vaikuṇṭha, because they were afraid of Kālakūṭa.

column1: brahmādayaścarṣigaṇāśca tadā pareśaṃ viṣṇuṃ purāṇapuruṣaṃ prabhaviṣṇumīśam | vaikuṇṭhamāśritamadhokṣajamādhavaṃ te sarve surāsuragaṇāḥ śaraṇaṃ prayātāḥ || 108 ||
column2: 108. Brahmā and others as well as the groups of sages sought refuge in the great lord Viṣṇu, the primordial Puruṣa, the mighty lord who had resorted to Vaikuṇṭha, Mādhava, Adhokṣaja. The groups of Suras and Asuras sought refuge in lord Viṣṇu.

column1: tāvatpravṛddhaṃ sumahatkālakūṭaṃ samabhyayāt | dagdhvādo brahmaṇo lokaṃ vaikuṇṭhaṃ ca dadāha vai || 109 ||
column2: 109. By that time, the great poison Kālakūṭa came there. After burning Brahmā’s world at the outset, it burned Vaikuṇṭha.

column1: kālakūṭāgninā dagdho viṣṇuḥ sarvaguhāśayaḥ | pārṣadaiḥ sahitaḥ sadyastamālasadṛśacchaviḥ || 110 ||
column2: 110. Viṣṇu who dwells in the cavity of the heart of everyone, was burned by the fire of Kālakūṭa also with his attendants. Immediately he acquired the colour of Tamāla.

column1: vaikuṇṭhaṃ ca sunīlaṃ ca sarvalokaiḥ samāvṛtam | jalakalmaṣasaṃvītāḥ sarve lokāstadābhavan || 111 ||
column2: 111. Vaikuṇṭha also became blue in colour. It was surrounded by all the worlds. Hence, all the worlds became encircled by the poisonous substance from the waters.

column1: aṣṭāvaraṇasaṃvītaṃ brahmāṃḍaṃ brahmaṇā saha | bhasmībhūtaṃ cakārāśu jalakalmaṣamadbhutam || 112 ||
column2: 112. The wonderful poison of the waters reduced to ash the whole of the Cosmic Egg with its eight outer coverings and along with Brahmā.

column1: nobhūmirna jalaṃ cāgnirna vāyurna nabhastadā | nāhaṃkāro na ca mahānmūlāvidyā tathaiva ca | śivasya kopātsaṃjātaṃ tadā bhasmākulaṃ jagat || 113 ||
column2: 113. There was no earth, no water, no fire, no wind, and no ether. There was neither Ahaṃkāra (Cosmic Ego), nor Mahat (the Great Principle). There was no Mūlāvidyā. On account of Śiva’s wrath, the entire universe became reduced to ash. Notes regarding the Churning of the Ocean: This is a favourite topic of Purāṇa-writers as can be seen from its description in Mbh, Ādi. 18, VR 1.45.17-18, BhP VIII.5.U-18, BdP I.ii.25, MtP 249-250 to mention a few. The background of the churning of the ocean is different in our text. It is for the recovery of the gems of Indra which were sunk into the sea that Devas and Asuras agreed to churn the ocean. In Mbh. it was god Nārāyaṇa who advised god Brahmā to churn the ocean for getting Amṛta (Ādi. 17.10-13).

column1: munaya ūcuḥ | yattvayā kathitaṃ brahmanbrahmāṃḍaṃ sacarācaram | bhasmībhūtaṃ rudrakopātkālakūṭāgninā'tha़khilam || 1 ||
column2: The sages said: 1. O holy Sir, you said that the Cosmic Egg including the mobile and immobile beings was entirely reduced to ash by the fire of Kālakūṭa on account of the wrath of Rudra.

column1: brahmāṃḍāṃtarataḥ kiṃ tu rudraṃ manyāmahe vayam | tadā carācaraṃ naṣṭaṃ brahmaviṣṇupurogamam || 2 || bhasmībhūtaṃ rudrakopātkathaṃ sṛṣṭiḥ pravartitā | kuto brahmā ca viṣṇuśca kutaścaṃdrapurogamāḥ || 3 || anye surā surāḥ kutra bhasmībhūtā layaṃ gatāḥ | ata ūrdhvaṃ kimabhavattatsarvaṃ vaktumarhasi || 4 ||
column2: 2-4. But, we consider Rudra to be within the Cosmic Egg. Then the mobile and immobile beings with Brahmā and Viṣṇu as leaders were destroyed and reduced to ash through the wrath of Rudra. How was creation resumed and made to function? Wherefrom did Brahmā, Viṣṇu and other Suras and Asuras with the Moon at their Head (originate again)? Where did they get merged? Where were they reduced to ash? What happened after that? It behoves you to recount everything.

column1: vyāsaprasādātsakalaṃ vettha tvaṃ nāparo hi tat | tasmājjñānamayaṃ śāstraṃ tajjānāsi na cāparaḥ || 5 ||
column2: 5. By the grace of Vyāsa you know everything. No one else knows it. Hence you understand the holy scripture full of knowledge as no one else does.

column1: iti pṛṣṭastadā sarvairmunibhirbhāvitātmabhiḥ | sūto vyāsaṃ namaskṛtya vākyaṃ cedamathābravīt || 6 ||
column2: 6. Asked thus by all those sages of sanctified souls, Sūta bowed down to Vyāsa and spoke these words:

column1: lomaśa uvāca | yadā brahmāṃḍamadhyasthā vyāptā devā viṣāgninā | haribrahmādayo hyete lokapālāḥ savāsavāḥ | tadā vijñāpitaḥ śaṃbhurheraṃbena mahātmanā || 7 ||
column2: Lomaśa said: 7. When Devas beginning with Hari and Brahmā, stationed in the middle of the Cosmic Egg, as well as the guardians of the worlds including Indra were enveloped by the fire of poison, Śaṃbhu was informed by the noble-souled Heraṃba (Gaṇeśa): Heraṃba said:

column1: heraṃba uvāca | he rudra he mahādeva he sthāṇo ha jagatpate | mayā vighnaṃ vinodena kṛtaṃ teṣāṃ sudurjayam || 8 || bhayena mati mohāttvāṃ nārccayaṃti ca māmapi | udyogaṃ ye prakurvanti teṣāṃ kleśo'dhiko bhavet || 9 || evamabhyarthitastena pinākī vṛṣabhadhvajaḥ | vighnāṃdhakārasūryeṇa gaṇādhipatinā tadā || 10 ||
column2: 8-9. O Rudra, O Mahādeva, O Sthāṇu, the lord of the universe, an obstacle very difficult to be surmounted has been created for them by me by way of amusement.[1] There are persons who start an enterprise, but either because of their fear or through the delusion of their minds, they do not worship you or me. The distress unto them will be very great.

column1: liṃgarūpo'bravīcchaṃbhurnirākāro nirāmayaḥ | niraṃjano vyomakeśaḥ kaparddī nīlalohitaḥ || 11 ||
column2: 10-11. On being requested thus by the over-lord of Gaṇas, who dispels obstacles like the sun dispelling darkness, the Pināka-bearing Lord with a bull for his emblem, the Lord Nīlalohita with matted hair, the lord devoid of ailments, the lord in the form of Liṅga, the unsullied lord without form or features, the sky-haired lord Śiva, Śaṃbhu spoke thus: Maheśvara said[3]:

column1: maheśvara uvāca | heraṃba śrṛṇu me vākyaṃ śraddhayā parayā yutaḥ | ahaṃkārātmakaṃ caiva jagadetaccarācaram || 12 || sthitiṃ karotyahaṃkāraḥ pralayotpattimeva ca | jagadādaugaṇapate tadā vijñaptimātrataḥ || 13 || māyāvirahitaṃ śāṃtaṃ dvaitādvaitaparaṃ sadā | jñaptimātrasvarūpaṃ tatsadānaṃdaikalakṣaṇam || 14 ||
column2: 12-14. O Heraṃba, listen to my words with great faith and attention. This universe consisting of the mobile and immobile beings is of the form of Ahaṃkāra (Cosmic Ego). This Ahaṃkāra creates, sustains and destroys. At the beginning of the universe, O Gaṇapati, Vijñapti (Intelligence, Consciousness) alone (remained). It was devoid of Māyā. īt was quiescent and of the form of Dvaita and Advaita (duality and non-duality). It was in the form of intelligence alone characterized by existence and eternal bliss.

column1: gaṇapatiruvāca | yadi tvaṃ kevalo hyātmā paramānandalakṣaṇaḥ | tasmāttvadaparaṃ kiṃcinnānyadasti paraṃtapa || 15 ||
column2: Gaṇapati said: 15. If you are the sole Ātman, characterized by supreme bliss, O Scorcher of foes, then there is nothing other than you.

column1: nānārūpaṃ kathaṃ jātaṃ surāsuravilakṣaṇam | vicitraṃ mohajananaṃ tribhirddevaiśca lakṣitam || 16 ||
column2: 16. Then how did the different forms originate, differentiated as Suras and Asuras? It is of variegated form observed by the three Devas. It is the cause of delusion.

column1: bhūtagrāmaiścaturbhiśca nānābhedaiḥ samanvitaiḥ | jātaṃ saṃsāracakraṃ ca nityānityavilakṣaṇam || 17 ||
column2: 17. The cycle of worldly existence originated as different from Nitya (eternal) and Anitya (transient). It consists of four types or species of living beings endowed with many distinctive features etc.

column1: parasparavirodhena jñānavādena mohitāḥ | karmavādaratāḥ kecitkecitsvaguṇamāśritāḥ || 18 ||
column2: 18. People are deluded by various doctrines and tenets of knowledge antagonistic to one another. Some are devoted to the doctrine of Karman. Some resort to their (intrinsic) qualities.

column1: jñānaniṣṭhāśca ye kecitparasparavirodhinaḥ | evaṃ saṃśayamāpannaṃ trāhi māṃ vṛṣabhadhvaja || 19 ||
column2: 19. A few are adherents of the path of knowledge but they are opposed to one another. O Bull-bānnered Lord, thus I have been overwhelmed by doubts. Save me (by dispelling the doubt).

column1: ahaṃ gaṇaśca kutratyāḥ kva cāyaṃ vṛṣabhaḥ prabho | ete cānye ca bahavaḥ kuto jātāśca kutra vai || 20 ||
column2: 20. Where do I and the Gaṇas belong to? Whence is this bull, O'Lord? From where are these and many others born? Where (do they go)?

column1: kṛtāḥ sarve mahābhāgāḥ sāttvikā rājasāśca vai | prahasya bhagavāñchaṃbhurgaṇeśaṃ vaktumudyataḥ || 21 ||
column2: 21. Whence are all these exceedingly fortunate ones made into Sāttvikas, Rājasas etc.? Lord Śaṃbhu laughed and began to speak to Gaṇeśa:

column1: maheśvara uvāca | kālaśaktyā ca jātāni rajaḥsattvatamāṃsi ca | tairāvṛtaṃ jagatsarvaṃ sadevāsumānuṣam || 22 ||
column2: Maheśvara said: 22. Rajas, Sattva and Tamas are produced by Kālaśakti (Power of Time). The entire universe including Devas, Asuras and human beings is enveloped by them.

column1: paridṛśyamānametaccānaśvaraṃ paramārthataḥ | viddhyetatsarvasiddhyaiva kṛtakatvācca naśvaram || 23 ||
column2: 23. This (world) that is being seen is imperishable ultimately, but, understand that as an evolved effect it is perishable. It is evolved by means of all Siddhis.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | yāvadgaṇeśasaṃyukto bhāṣamāṇaḥ sadāśivaḥ | liṃgarūpī viśvarūpaḥ prādurbhūtā sadāśivāt || 24 || śivarūpā jagadyoniḥ kāryakāraṇarūpiṇī | liṃgarūpī sa bhagavānnimagnastatkṣaṇādabhūt || 25 ||
column2: 24-25. While Sadāśiva of Cosmic Form and in the form of the Liṅga was conversing with Gaṇeśa, His Power (Śakti called Śiva), the source of the universe of the nature of cause and effect was born of Sadāśiva. At the same instant, the Lord in the form of the Liṅga became submerged.

column1: ekā sthitā parā śaktirbrahmavidyātmalakṣaṇā | gaṇeśo vismayāviṣṭo hyavalokanatatparaḥ || 26 ||
column2: 26. The single supreme Śakti, characterized as the Ātman of Brahmavidyā abided (there). Overwhelmed by wonder, Gaṇeśa became engrossed in looking (at that form).

column1: ṛṣaya ūcuḥ | prakṛtyantargataṃ sarvaṃ jagadetaccarācaram | gaṇeśasya pṛthaktvaṃ ca kathaṃ jātaṃ taducyatām || 27 ||
column2: The sages asked: 27. If this entire universe consisting of the mobile and immobile beings is included within Prakṛti, how is it then that Gaṇeśa was able to preserve his separate entity? Let this be explained.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | sākṣātprakṛtyāḥ saṃbhūto gaṇeśo bhagavānabhūt | yathārūpaḥ śivaḥ sākṣāttadrūpo hi gaṇeśvaraḥ || 28 ||
column2: Lomaśa replied: 28. Lord Gaṇeśa was directly born of Prakṛti herself.[4] Gaṇeśvara has the same form as that of Śiva himself.

column1: śivena saha saṃgrāmo hyabhūttasya mahātmanaḥ | ajñānātprakṛto bhūtvā bahukālaṃ nirantaram || 29 ||
column2: 29-30. A battle ensued between Śiva and that noble-souled one who had been Prākṛta (born of Prakṛti) due to ignorance. That battle continued without a break for a long time.

column1: tasya dṛṣṭvā hyajeyatvaṃ gajārūḍhasya tattadā | triśūlenāhanacchaṃbhuḥ sagajaṃ tamapātayat || 30 ||
column2: On observing that he was invincible as long as he was riding an elephant, Śaṃbhu hit him with his trident and toppled him down along with the elephant.

column1: tadā stuto mahādevaḥ paraśaktyā paraṃtapaḥ | paraśaktimuvācedaṃ varaṃ varaya śobhane || 31 ||
column2: 31. Then Mahādeva the scorcher of enemies, was eulogized by the Supreme Power (Prakṛti). The lord then said to the great Śakti, “O splendid lady, choose your boon.”

column1: tadā vṛto mahādevo vareṇa parameṇa hi | yo'yaṃ tvayā hato deva mama putro na saṃśayaḥ || 32 || tvāṃ na jānātyayaṃ mūḍhaḥ prakṛtyaṃśasamudbhavaḥ | tasmātputraṃ jīvayemaṃ mama tṛṣṭyarthameva ca || 33 ||
column2: 32-33. Then an excellent boon was chosen from Mahādeva: “O lord, he who was killed by you was undoubtedly my son. Being born of a part of Prakṛti, he is deluded. Hence he does not know you. In order to gratify me, resuscitate this son of mine.”

column1: prahasya bhagavānrudro māyāputramajīvayat | siṃdhuravadanenaiva mukhe sa samayojayat || 34 ||
column2: 34. Lord Rudra laughed loudly and revived the son of Māyā. He fixed the head of an elephant to his body.

column1: tadā gajānano jātaḥ prasādācchaṃkarasya ca | māyāputropi nirmāyo jñānavānsaṃbabhūva ha || 35 ||
column2: 35. Thus the elephant-faced lord was born by the grace of Śaṅkara. Although he was the son of Māyā, he was free from the clutches of Māyā and became endowed with (spiritual) knowledge.

column1: ātmajñānāmṛtenaiva nityatṛpto nirāmayaḥ | samādhisaṃsthito raudraḥ kālakālāṃtako'bhavat || 36 ||
column2: 36. He was perpetually contented with the nectar of the knowledge of Ātman. He was free from ailments. Sitting in deep meditation, he became very fierce and then destroyed Kāla (god of death) of black complexion.

column1: yogadaṃḍārthamutpāṭya svakīyaṃ daśanaṃ mahat | kare gṛhya gaṇādhyakṣaḥ śabdhabrahmātivarttate | ṛddhisiddhidvayenaiva ekatvena virājitaḥ || 37 ||
column2: 37. He pulled out his own huge tooth for the sake of Yogadaṇḍa[5] (the mystic wand of Yogic practice) and held it in his hand. He was the presiding deity of the Gaṇas. He surpasses the Śabdabrahman (the Vedas or the supreme spiritual knowledge expressed in words). Though accompanied by both Ṛddhi and Siddhi, he shines in his aloneness.

column1: ye te gaṇāśca vighnāśca ye cānye'bhyadhikā bhuvi | teṣāmapi patirjātaḥ kṛto'sau śaṃbhunā tadā || 38 ||
column2: 38. The groups of Gaṇas and Vighnas (obstacles) and many others superior to these—whatever there was on the earth, he became the lord thereof. He was made so by Śaṃbhu then.

column1: tasmādvi lokayāmāsa prakṛtiṃ viśvarūpiṇīm | pṛthaksthitvāgrato jānālliṃgaṃ prakṛtimeva ca | dadarśa vimalaṃ liṃgaṃ prakṛtisthaṃ svabhāvataḥ || 39 || ātmānaṃ ca gaṇaiḥ sāddhaṃ tathaiva ca jagattrayam | līnaṃ liṃge samastaṃ taddherambo jñānavānapi || 40 ||
column2: 39. Hence he was able to see Prakṛti which has the Cosmic form. He remained separate and was able to realize the Liṅga as well as the Prakṛti. He saw the pure Liṅga naturally abiding in the Prakṛti. 40. Heraṃba who was equipped with perfect knowledge saw himself along with the Gaṇas as well as the three worlds entirely merged in the Liṅga.

column1: mumoha ca punaḥ saṃjñāṃ pratilabhya prayatnataḥ | nanāma śirasā tābhyāmīśābhyāṃ sa gaṇeśvaraḥ || 41 ||
column2: 41. Though he was endowed with perfect knowledge, he lost his consciousness. He regained it with very great effort. The lord of the Gaṇas bowed down his head to those two supreme powers.

column1: tadā dadarśa tatraiva lokasaṃhārakārakam | brahmāṇaṃ caiva rudraṃ ca viṣṇuṃ caiva sadāśivam || 42 ||
column2: 42. Then he saw there itself Brahmā, Rudra, Viṣṇu and Sadāśiva in the form of the annihilator of the worlds.

column1: dadarśa pretatulyāni liṃgaśaktyātmakāni ca | brahmāṇḍagolakānyeva koṭiśaḥ paramāṇuvat || 43 || līyaṃte ca vilīyaṃte maheśe liṃgarūpiṇi | prakṛtyaṃtargataṃ liṃgaṃ liṃgasyāṃtargatā ca sā || 44 ||
column2: 43-45. He saw some beings resembling ghosts. They were the Liṅgaśaktis. He saw crores of spherical Cosmic Eggs like so many atoms. They were getting merged and dissolved in Maheśa who was in the form of a Liṅga.

column1: śaktyā liṃgaṃ ca saṃchannaṃ tadā sarvamadṛśyata | liṃgena śaktiḥ saṃchannā parasparamavartata || 45 ||
column2: The Liṅga was inside the Prakṛti and the Prakṛti was within the Liṅga. The whole of the Liṅga was seen covered by Śakti. The Śakti was covered by the Liṅga. Thus the two encompassed each other.{GL_NOTE::}

column1: śivābhyāṃ saṃśritaṃ lokaṃ jagadetaccarācaram | gaṇeśo vāpi tajjñānaṃ na pare'pi tathāvidan || 46 ||
column2: 46. The whole world consisting of the mobile and immobile beings stayed supported by both Śivas (i.e. Śiva ānd Śakti). Only Gaṇeśa and none else, though great, had that knowledge.

column1: tadovāca mahātejā gaṇādhyakṣo gaṇaiḥ saha | saśaktikaṃ stūyamānaḥ śaktyā ca parayā tadā || 47 ||
column2: 47. The presiding deity of the Gaṇas (Lord Gaṇeśa), of great splendour, accompanied by the Gaṇas eulogized with great strength, the lord accompanied by Śakti.

column1: gaṇeśa uvāca | namāmi devaṃ śaktyānvitaṃ jñānarūpaṃ prasannaṃ jñānātparaṃ paramaṃjyotirūpam | rūpātparaṃ paramaṃ tattvarūpaṃ tattvātparaṃ paramaṃ maṃgalaṃ ca ānaṃdākhyaṃ niṣkalaṃ nirviṣādam || 48 ||
column2: Gaṇeśa prayed: 48. I bow down to the god accompanied by His Śakti (Power)—the Lord who is the embodiment of knowledge, who is kindly disposed (but) beyond the ken of knowledge and of the form of supreme Light, who transcends forms, is the Supreme Reality incarnate, who is beyond the principles (categories of Sāṅkhyas), supremely auspicious, who is called Bliss undivided and uncontaminated by sorrow.

column1: dhūmātparamayovahnirdhūmavatpratibhāsate | prakṛtyaṃtargastvaṃ hi lakṣyase jñānisaṃbhavaḥ | prakṛtyaṃtargatastvaṃ hi māyāvyaktiritīyase || 49 ||
column2: 49-50. The fire in (a ball of) iron is beyond smoke (smokeless), but it appears as though filled with smoke. You who are the source of knowledge, appear to be within Prakṛti. You who are present within the Prakṛti by Māyā, are spoken of as manifested.

column1: evaṃvidhastvaṃ bhagavansvamāyayā sṛjasyatholuṃpasi pāsi viśvam | asmādgarātsarvamidaṃ pranaṣṭaṃ sabrahmavipreṃdrayutaṃ carācaram || 50 ||
column2: You whose nature is such, O lord, create, annihilate and protect the universe by your Māyā. On account of this poison, the entire universe consisting of the mobile and immobile beings and accompanied by Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Indra, has been destroyed.

column1: yathā purāsīrbhagavānmaheśastrailokyanātho'si carācarātmā | kuruṣya śīghraṃ sahajīvakośaṃ carācaraṃ tatsakalaṃ pradagdham || 51 ||
column2: 51. You are lord Maheśa. You are the lord of the three worlds. You are the immanent soul of the mobile and immobile beings. The mobile and immobile beings along with the vestures of individual souls, have been completely burnt down. Please revive them quickly and make it (the world) as it was before.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | evaṃ stuto gaṇeśena bhagavānbhūtabhāvanaḥ | yadutthitaṃ kālakūṭaṃ lokasaṃhārakārakam || 52 || liṃgarūpeṇa tadgrastaṃ vimalaṃ cākarottadā | sadevāsuramartyāśca sarvāṇi trijaganti ca | tatkṣaṇādrakṣitānyeva kṛpayā parayā yutaḥ || 53 ||
column2: 52-54. On being eulogized thus by Gaṇeśa, the Lord (Siva), the sanctifier of all living beings, assumed the form of a Liṅga and consumed the Kālakūṭa that arose there and caused the destruction of all the worlds. He made everything free from impurities. Since the lord was endowed with great compassion and considerateness, all Devas, Asuras and human beings and all the three worlds were instantaneously saved.

column1: brahmā viṣṇuḥ sureṃdraśca lokapālāḥ saharṣayaḥ | yakṣā vidyādharāḥ siddhā gaṃdharvāpsarasāṃ gaṇāḥ | utthitāścaiva te sarve nidrāparigatā iva || 54 ||
column2: Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Surendra, the Guardians of the Quarters along with the sages, Yakṣas, Vidyādharas, Siddhas, Gandharvas and groups of celestial damsels—all of them got up as though from sleep.

column1: vismayena samāviṣṭā babhūvurjātasādhvasāḥ | sarve devāsurāścaiva ūcurāścaryavattataḥ || 55 ||
column2: 55. They were struck with wonder. They were agitated and frightened. All Devas and Asuras said in dismay:

column1: kva kālakūṭaṃ sumahadyena vidrāvitā vayam | mṛtaprāyāḥ kṛtāḥ sadyaḥ salokapālakā hyamī || 56 || ityabruvaṃstadā daityāstūṣṇīṃbhūtāstadā sthitāḥ | śakrādayo lokapālā viṣṇuṃ sarveśvareśvaram | brahmāṇaṃ ca puraskṛtya idamūcuḥ samedhitā || 57 ||
column2: 56-62. “Where is that immense Kālakūṭa by which we had been compelled to flee and made almost dead along with the Guardians of the Quarters?” So said they, but Daityas remained silent. The Guardians of the Quarters beginning with Śakra, who were able to regain strength and happiness with god Brahmā as their leader, said this after honouring Viṣṇu, the lord of all lords:

column1: kenedaṃ kāritaṃ viṣṇo na vidāmo'lpamedhasaḥ | tadā prahasya bhagavānbrahmaṇā saha taiḥ suraiḥ || 58 || samādhimagamansarve'pyekāgramanasastadā | tattvajñānena nirhṛtya kāmakrodādikāndvijāḥ || 59 || tadātmani sthitaṃ liṃgamapaśyanvi budhādayaḥ | viṣṇuṃ puraskṛtya tadā tuṣṭuvuḥ paramārthataḥ || 60 ||
column2: “By whom has this been caused? We do not know as we are deficient in intelligence.” Then Viṣṇu laughed at Brahmā and all those (Suras). All of them then began to meditate with great concentration of their minds. O Brāhmaṇas, that dispelled base emotions such as lust and anger as well as other feelings by means of the knowledge of Reality. Then Devas and others saw the Liṅga present in their own Ātman (Soul). Keeping Viṣṇu at their head, they eulogized the Lord for the attainment of the ultimate truth:

column1: ātmanā paramātmānaṃ yoginaḥ paryupāsate || 61 || liṃgameva paraṃ jñānaṃ liṃgameva paraṃ tapaḥ | liṃgameva paro dharmo liṃgameva parā gatiḥ | tasmālliṃgātparataraṃ yacca kiṃcinna vidyate || 62 ||
column2: “Yogins worship the Supreme Soul through their own souls. The Liṅga alone is the greatest knowledge. The Liṅga alone is the greatest penance. The Liṅga alone is the greatest Dharma. The Liṅga alone is the greatest goal. Hence, there is nothing at all which (can be called) greater than the Liṅga.”

column1: evaṃ bruvaṃto hi tadā surāsurāḥ salokapālā ṛṣibhiśca sākam | viṣṇuṃ puraskṛtya tamālavarṇaṃ śaṃbhuṃ śaraṇyaṃ śaraṇaṃ prapannāḥ || 63 ||
column2: 63. After saying thus, Suras and Asuras along with the Guardians of the Quarters and sages kept Viṣṇu whose complexion is dark like the Indian cinnamon, at their head. They then sought refuge in Śaṃbhu who is worthy of being resorted to:

column1: trāhitrāhi mahādeva kṛpālo parameśvara | purā trātā yathā sarve tathātvaṃ trātumarhasi || 64 ||
column2: 64. “Save us, save us, O Mahādeva, O merciful lord, O Supreme God. It behoves you to save us as we had been saved before (by you).

column1: taddevadeva bhavataścaraṇāraviṃdaṃ sevānubaṃdhamahimānamanaṃtarūpam | tvadāśritaṃ yatparamānukaṃpayā namo'stu te devavara prasīda || 65 ||
column2: 65. O Lord of Devas, your lotus-like feet possess greatness befitting our repeated service. They have infinite forms. We have resorted to them. (Save us) with the greatest mercy. Obeisance to you, O excellent one among Devas. Be pleased.”

column1: liṃgasvarūpamadhyastho bhagavānbhūtabhāvanaḥ | sarvaiḥ suragaṇaiḥ sākaṃ babhāṣedaṃ ramāpatiḥ || 66 ||
column2: 66. Lord Ramāpati (Viṣṇu), the sanctifier of the living beings, stood in the middle of the form of Liṅga along with ail the groups of Suras and spoke thus:

column1: tvaṃ liṃgarūpī bhagavāñjagatāmabhayapradaḥ | viṣṇunā saṃstuto devo liṃgarūpī maheśvaraḥ || 67 || mṛtāstrātā garātsarve tasmānmṛtyuṃjaya prabho | rakṣarakṣa mahākāla tripurāṃta namostu te || 68 ||
column2: 67-69. “You are the Lord in the form of the Liṅga. You bestow protection from fear on all the worlds. All those who died on account of the poison, have been saved. Hence, O Lord, the conqueror of Mṛtyu (Death), save us, save us. O Mahākāla, the destroyer of Tripura, obeisance to you.”

column1: viṣṇunā saṃstuto devo liṃgarūpī maheśvaraḥ | prādurbabhūva sāṃbo'tha bodhayanniva tānsurān || 69 ||
column2: On being eulogized by Viṣṇu, Lord Maheśvara in the form of the Liṅga appeared before them along with Aṃbā (goddess Pārvatī). He appeared to awaken (i.e. enlighten) those Suras:

column1: he viṣṇo he surāḥ sarva ṛṣayaḥ śrūyatāmidam | manyate'pi hi saṃsāre anitye nityatākulam || 70 || avilokayatā'tmātmanā vibudhādayaḥ | kiṃ yajñaiḥ kiṃ tapobhiśca kimudyogena karmaṇām || 71 || ekatvena pṛthaktvena kiṃcinnaiva prayojanam | yasmādbhavadbhirmilitaiḥ kṛtaṃ yatkarma duṣkaram || 72 ||
column2: 70-74. “O Viṣṇu, ye all Suras and Sages, let this be heard. Ordinary people think that the worldly existence is eternal, while it is only transitory. Thereby, they are agitated. O Devas and others, of what avail are the Yajñas, austerities and activities connected with holy rites, if one does not perceive the (Supreme) Ātman by means of (his individual Ātman)? There is no benefit therefrom, whether they are performed collectively or separately. All of you joined together and carried out a very difficult task, namely the churning of the ocean. T??? you did for the sake of getting nectar. But why was it performed after rejecting Mṛtyuñjaya and always disrespecting me? Hence all of you undoubtedly fell into the mouth of Death.

column1: tasmātsarve mṛtyumukhaṃ patitā vai na saṃśayaḥ | asmābhirnirmito devo gaṇeśaḥ kāryasiddhaye || 74 ||
column2: Lord Gaṇeśa has been created by us for the purpose of achieving success in an undertaking.

column1: na namaṃti gaṇeśaṃ ca durgāṃ caiva tathāvidhām | kleśabhājo bhaviṣyati nātra kāryā vicāraṇā || 75 ||
column2: 75. Those who do not bow down to Gaṇeśa as well as Durgā of similar nature will be victims of distress. There is no doubt about this.

column1: yūyaṃ sarve tvadharmiṣṭhāḥ stabdhāḥ paṃḍitamāninaḥ | kāryākāryamavijñāya kevalaṃ mānamohitāḥ || 76 ||
column2: 76. All of you are sinful and stubborn. You profess to be learned without knowing what is right and what is wrong. You are deluded by mere false prestige.

column1: prarocanaparāḥ sarve kṣudrāśceṃdrādayo vṛthā | nātmānaṃ ca prapaṃcena vetsi tvaṃ hi śacīpate || 78 ||
column2: 77-78. All of you, groups of Devas beginning with Indra, are devoted to the Vedas. All those beginning with Indra are mediocres, pleasure-seekers, praise-mongers and useless ones. O consort of Śacī (i.e. Indra), you do not understand yourself on account of delusion.

column1: kṛtaḥ prayatno hi mahānamṛtārthaṃ tvayā śaṭha | aśvamedhaśatenaiva yadrājyaṃ prāptavānasi | api tacca parādhīna tanna jānāsi durmate || 79 ||
column2: 79. A great effort has been made by you for getting nectar, O rogue. You attained a kingdom by performing a hundred horse-sacrifices. Even that is under the control of your enemies now. O vicious one, you do not know that.

column1: yairvadavākyaistvaṃ mūḍha saṃstuto'si tapasvibhiḥ | te mūḍhāsto ṣayaṃti tvāṃ tattadrāgaparāyaṇāḥ || 80 ||
column2: 80. O deluded one, you have been eulogized by ascetics through the Vedic statements (hymns). Those ascetics are fools. They propitiate you, because they are prompted by different passions.

column1: viṣṇo tvaṃ ca pakṣapātānna jānāsi hitāhitam | kecidadhatāstvayā viṣṇo rakṣitāścaiva kecana || 81 ||
column2: 81. O Viṣṇu, on account of your partiality you do not know what is good and what is otherwise. Some persons are killed by you, O Viṣṇu, and some have been protected.

column1: icchāyuktastvamatraiva sadā bālakaceṣṭitaḥ | ye'nye ca lokapāḥ sarve teṣāṃ vārtā kutastviha || 82 ||
column2: 82. You are desirous of certain things in this matter. You are always childish in your activities. Why talk of all the other Guardians of the Quarters?

column1: anyathā hi kṛte hyarthe anyathātvaṃ bhaviṣyati | kāryasiddhirbhavedyena bhavadbhirvismṛtaṃ ca tat || 83 ||
column2: 83. If a matter is pursued in a way other than what is proper, the result is bound to be in a way other than (what is expected). You all forgot that thing whereby your efforts are crowned with success.

column1: yenādya rakṣitāḥ sarve kālakūṭamahābhayāt | yena nīlīkṛto viṣṇuryena sarve parājitāḥ || 84 || lokā bhasmīkṛtā yena tasmādyenāpi rakṣitāḥ | tasyārccanāvidhiḥ kāryo gaṇeśasya mahātmanaḥ || 85 ||
column2: 84-85. It is he by whom all (of you) have been saved from the great fear of Kālakūṭa today. It is he by whom you have been saved from a poison by which Viṣṇu is turned blue (dark-complexioned), by which all of you were defeated and by which all the worlds have been reduced to ash. Hence, the worship of that noble-souled Gaṇeśa should be performed by you.

column1: karmāraṃbhe tu vighneśaṃ ye nārcaṃti gaṇādhipam | kāryasiddhirna teṣāṃ vai bhavettu bhavatāṃ yathā || 86 ||
column2: 86. If at the beginning of any holy rite, people do not worship Gaṇādhipa (Gaṇeśa), they will never realize their objectives as in your own case.”

column1: etanmaheśasya vaco niśamya surāsurāḥ kiṃnaracāraṇāśca | pūjāvidhānaṃ paramārthato'pi papracchurenaṃ ca tadā girīśam || 87 ||
column2: 87. On hearing these words of Maheśa, Suras, Asuras, Kinnaras and Cāraṇas asked Girīśa about the method of worship in the proper manner. FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES:

column1: maheśvara uvāca | pratipakṣe caturthyāṃ tu pūjanīyo gaṇādhipaḥ | snātvā śuklatilaiḥ śuddhaiḥ śuklapakṣe sadā nṛbhiḥ || 1 ||
column2: Maheśvara said: 1. In every fortnight Gaṇeśa should be worshipped on the fourth day. (But) in the bright half of the month a devotee, after taking bath, should worship always with white sesamum seeds.[1]

column1: kṛtvā cāvasyakaṃ sarvaṃ gaṇeśasyārcanakriyām | prayatnenaiva kurvīta gaṃdhamālyākṣatādibhiḥ || 2 ||
column2: 2. After finishing all necessary daily routine religious duties, the devotee should perform the worship of Gaṇeśa with great care, by means of scents, garlands, akṣatas (raw unbroken rice grains) etc.

column1: dhyānamādau prakartavyaṃ gaṇeśasya yathāvidhi | āgamā bahavo jātā gaṇeśasya yathā mama || 3 ||
column2: 3. At the outset, meditation on Gaṇeśa should be performed in. accordance with scriptural injunctions.

column1: bahudhopāsakā yasmāttamaḥ sattvarajonvitāḥ | gaṇabhedena tānyeva nāmāni bahudhā'bhavat || 4 ||
column2: 4. As the worshippers are of various types having Tāmasa, Sāttvika and Rājasa traits, the names also (of Gaṇeśa) became many in number according to their class (characterized by a particular Guṇa).

column1: paṃcavaktro gaṇādhyakṣo daśabāhustrilocanaḥ | kāṃtasphaṭikasaṃkāśo nīlakaṃṭho gajānanaḥ || 5 ||
column2: 5. They are as follows: Pañcavaktra (Five-faced), Gaṇādhyakṣa (Chief of the Gaṇas—Śiva’s attendants), Daśabāhu (Ten-armed), Trilocana (Three-eyed), Kāntasphaṭika-saṅkāśa (Resembling a shining crystal), Nīlakaṇṭha (Blue-throated), Gajānana (Elephant-faced).

column1: mukhāni tasya paṃcaiva kathayāmi yatātatham || 6 ||
column2: 6. I shall describe his five faces correctly.

column1: madhyamaṃ tu mukhaṃ gauraṃ caturdantaṃ trilocanam | śuṃḍādaṃḍamanojñaṃ ca puṣkare modakānvitam || 7 ||
column2: 7. The middle face is fair in colour with four teeth and three eyes. It is beautiful with a long trunk. In the trunk he keeps a modaka (a round piece of sweetmeat).

column1: tathānyatpītavarṇaṃ ca nīlaṃ ca śubhalakṣaṇam | piṃgalaṃ ca tathā śubhraṃ gaṇeśasya śubhānanam || 8 ||
column2: 8. The other faces of Gaṇeśa are yellow, auspicious blue, tawny and grey. The faces are splendid and characterized by good features.

column1: tathā daśabhujeṣveva hyāyudhāni bravīmi vaḥ | pāśaṃ pasśupadme ca aṃkuśaṃ daṃtameva ca || 9 ||
column2: 9-10. I shall tell you the weapons in the ten hands (of Gaṇeśa). They are: noose, axe, lotus, goad, tusk, rosary, ploughshare, pestle, varada (mudrā—gesture) (the hand indicating bestowal of boons) and a vessel containing modakas. One should meditate that he is holding the vessel in his hand.

column1: laṃbodara virūpākṣaṃ nivītaṃ mekhalānvitam | yogāsane copaviṣṭaṃ caṃdralekhāṃ kaśekharam || 11 ||
column2: 11-14. The meditation is of three types. In Sāttvika meditation contemplate thus: (He is) Laṃbodara (Pot-bellied). Virūpākṣa (of uneven eyes = three-eyed), Nivīta (sacred thread worn like a garland). He is having a girdle. He is seated in the Yogic posture; the crescent-moon adorns his head.

column1: caturbhujaṃ trinayanamekadaṃtaṃ mahodaram | pāśāṃkuśadharaṃ devaṃ daṃtamodakapātrakam || 13 ||
column2: Rājasa meditation is as in the case of men. The deity has pure golden complexion. (He is) elephant-faced and super-natural. He has four hands, three eyes, one tusk and huge belly.

column1: nīlaṃ ca tāmasaṃ dhyānamevaṃ trividhamucyate | tataḥ pūjā prakartavyā bhavadbhiḥ śīghrameva ca || 14 ||
column2: Thus there are three types of Dhyāna. Thereafter, the worship should be begun quickly by you all.

column1: ekaviṃśatidūrvābhirdvābhyāṃ nāmnā pṛthakpṛthak | sarvanāmabhirekaiva dīyate gaṇanāyake || 15 ||
column2: 15. Twenty-one Dūrvā grass-blades are (to be) taken. Two blades of grass are offered after uttering one name. (Thus ten names are uttered and twenty blades of grass are offered.) In the end, all the names are uttered and one blade of grass is offered to the lord of Gaṇas.

column1: tathaiva nāmabhirdeyā ekaviṃśatimodakāḥ | daśanāmānyahaṃ vakṣye pūjanārthaṃ pṛthakpṛthak || 16 ||
column2: 16. Similarly twenty-one modakas should be offered. I shall mention the ten names intended for worshipping separately.

column1: gaṇādhipa namastestu umāputrāghanāśana | vināyakeśaputroti sarvasiddhipradāyaka || 17 || ekadaṃtebhavaktreti tathā mūṣakavāhana | kumāragurave tubhyaṃ pūjanīyaḥ prayatnataḥ || 18 ||
column2: 17-18. The names are: 1. Gaṇādhipa (Lord of Gaṇas), 2. Umāputra (Son of Umā), 3. Aghanāśana (Destroyer of sins), 4. Vināyāka, 5. Īśaputra (Son of Lord Śiva), 6. Sarvasiddhipratdāyaka (Bestower of all Siddhis), 7. Ekadanta (One-tusked), 8. Ibhavaktra (Elephant-faced), 9. Mūṣakavāhana (Mouse-vehicled) and 10. Kumāraguru (The elder brother of Kumāra). At the end of every word namaste'stu (Obeisance to you) should be added. In the case of the last, the words Kumāragurave tubhyaṃ namo’stu, ‘Obeisance to you, O Kumāraguru’ should be uttered. Thus Gaṇeśa should be worshipped with care.

column1: evamuktvā surānsadyaḥ pariṣvajya ca sādaram | viṣṇuṃ guhāśayaṃ sadyo brahmāṇaṃ ca sadāśivaḥ || 19 || tirodhāna gataḥ sadyaḥ śaṃbhuḥ paramaśobhanaḥ | praṇamya śaṃbhuṃ te sarve gaṇādhyakṣārccane ratāḥ || 20 ||
column2: 19-20. After speaking thus to Suras, Sadāśiva, Śaṃbhu, the highly splendid lord, eagerly embraced Viṣṇu who abides in the cavity of heart, as well as Brahmā, and (he) immediately vanished. All of them bowed down to Śaṃbhu and then became engaged in worshipping Gaṇādhyakṣa (Gaṇeśa).

column1: tataḥ saṃpūjya vidhivadgaṇādhyakṣārccane ratāḥ | upacārairanekaiśca dūrvābhiśca pṛthakpṛthak || 21 ||
column2: 21. After worshipping him in accordance with the injunctions, they became engaged in honouring him with various Upacāras (ways of service) and the Dūrvā grass blades separately.

column1: saṃtuṣṭo hi gaṇādhyakṣo devānāṃ varado'bhavat | pradakṣiṇaṃ namaskṛtya taiḥ sarvairabhitoṣitaḥ || 22 ||
column2: 22. Gaṇeśa who was contented and delighted (by their worship) bestowed boons on Devas. They circumambulated him, bowed down to him and propitiated him.

column1: tamoguṇānvitāḥ sarve hyasurā nābhyapūjayan | upahāsaparāste vai devānpratyasurottamāḥ || 23 ||
column2: 23. Asuras who possessed only Tamas Guṇa did not worship Gaṇeśa.[2] The excellent Asuras were engaged in ridiculing Devas.

column1: pūjayitvā śāṃkariṃ te punaḥ kṣīrārṇavaṃ yayuḥ | brahmā viṣṇuśca ṛṣayo devadaityāḥ surottamāḥ || 24 || maṃthānaṃ maṃdaraṃ kṛtvā rajjuṃ kṛtvātha vāsukim | mamaṃthuśca tadā devā viṣṇuṃ kṛtvātha sannidhau || 25 ||
column2: 24-25. Devas finished worshipping the son of Śaṅkara and went to the Milk Ocean once again. Brahmā, Viṣṇu, the excellent Suras, Devas, Daityas and sages made Mandara the churning rod and Vāsuki the churning rope. Keeping Viṣṇu near them, Devas began the churning.

column1: mathyamāne tadābdhau ca nirgataścaṃdra agrataḥ | pīyūṣapūrṇaḥ sarveṣāṃ devānāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 26 ||
column2: 26. When the ocean was being churned, it was the Moon that came out at the outset,[3] for the purpose of realizing the objectives of all Devas. He was full of nectar.

column1: śaunaka uvāca | arṇave kiṃ purā caṃdro nikṣiptaḥ kena suvrata | gajādikāni ratnāni kathitāni tvayā purā || 27 || etatsarvaṃ samāsena ādau kathaya me prabho | jñātvā sarve vayaṃ sūta paścādāvarṇayāmahe || 28 ||
column2: Śaunaka said: 27-29. O sage of holy rites, was the Moon formerly placed in the ocean? By whom was he placed? It was told by you formerly that the excellent gems like the elephant etc. (had been cast into the ocean). O lord, tell me all these things briefly in the beginning. After understanding these, all of us shall later describe them.

column1: teṣāṃ tadvacanaṃ śrutvā sūto vākyamupādade || 29 ||
column2: On hearing their words, Sūta began his narrative:

column1: caṃdra āpomayo viprā atriputro guṇānvitaḥ | utpanno hyanasūyāyāṃ brahmaṇoṃ'śātsamudbhavaḥ | rudrasyāṃśāddhi durvāsā viṣṇoraṃśāttu dattakaḥ || 30 ||
column2: 30. Candra (the Moon) is watery by nature, O Brāhmaṇas. He was born as the son of Atri. He was endowed with all good qualities. He was born of Anasūya from a part of Brahmā. Durvāsas was born from a part of Rudra and Dattaka (i.e. Datta) was born from a part of Viṣṇu.

column1: kṣīrābdhiṃ mathyamānaṃ tu dṛṣṭvā caṃdro mudānvitaḥ | kṣīrābdhirapi caṃdraṃ ca dṛṣṭvā so'pyutsuko'bhavat || 31 ||
column2: 31. On seeing the Milk Ocean being churned, Candra became delighted. On seeing the Moon, the Milk Ocean too became extremely attached to him.

column1: praviṣṭaścobhayaprītyā śrṛṇvatāṃ bho dvijottamāḥ | caṃdro hyamṛta pūrṇobhūdagrato devasannidhau || 32 ||
column2: 32. Since both of them liked each other, Candra entered the Ocean. Let this be heard, O excellent Brāhmaṇas. In front of and in the presence of Devas, Candra became filled with nectar.

column1: dṛṣṭvā ca kāṃtiṃ tvarito'tha caṃdro nīrājito devagaṇaistadānīm | vāditragoṣaistumulairanekairmṛdaṃgaśaṃkhaiḥ paṭahairanekaiḥ || 33 ||
