column2: 33. On seeing the splendour of Candra, the Nīrājana rite (waving light around the face) was immediately performed by the groups of Devas with respect to Candra, along with the loud and tumultuous sounds of musical instruments, drums of many types and conchs.

column1: namaścakruśca te sarve sasurāsuradānavāḥ | tadā gargaṃ pṛcchamānā balaṃ caṃdrasya tattvataḥ || 34 ||
column2: 34. They all then bowed down to him along with Suras, Asuras and Dānavas. Then they asked Garga about the genuine inherent power of Candra.[4]

column1: gargeṇoktāstadā sarveṣāṃ balamadya vai | keṃdrasthānagatāḥ sarve bhavatāmuttamā grahāḥ || 35 || caṃdraṃ muruḥ samāyāto budhaścaiva samāgataḥ | ādityaśca tathā śukraḥ śaniraṃgārako mahān || 36 || tasmāccaṃdrabalaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ bhavatāṃ kāryasiddhaye | gomaṃtasaṃjñakonāma muhūrto'yaṃ jayapradaḥ || 37 ||
column2: 35-37. Thereupon, Garga told them, “All the Planets are powerful today. All the excellent Planets are in their central positions. (Therefore they are beneficial) to you. Guru (Jupiter) has come in conjunction with Candra (the Moon). Budha (Mercury) has also come in his contact. So also the Sun, Śukra (Venus), Śani (Saturn) and the great Planet Aṅgāraka (Mars). Hence the power and influence of Candra is very excellent for the realization of your objectives. This Muhūrta (auspicious time) named Gomanta[5] is the bestower of victory.”

column1: evamāśvāsitā devā gargeṇaiva mahātmanā | mamaṃthurabdhiṃ tvaritā garjamānā mahābalāḥ || 38 ||
column2: 38. At this encouraging assurance of the noble-souled Garga, the mighty Devas began to churn the ocean vigorously and roared (lustily in their eagerness).

column1: dviguṇaṃ balamāpannā mahātmāno dṛḍhavratāḥ | maheśaṃ smaramāṇāste gaṇeśaṃ ca punaḥ punaḥ || 39 ||
column2: 39. Remembering Maheśa and Gaṇeśa again and again, those noble-souled (Devas) of firm holy rites attained double strength.

column1: nirmathyamānādudadhergarjamānācca sarvaśaḥ | nirgatā surabhiḥ sākṣāddevānāṃ kāryasiddhaye || 40 ||
column2: 40. During churning, Surabhi (divine cow) came out directly for the sake of the accomplishment of the tasks of Devas, from the ocean that was roaring with a rumbling sound on all sides.

column1: tuṣṭā kapilavarṇāṃ sā ūdhobhāreṇa bhūyasā | taraṃgopari gacchaṃtī śanakaiḥ śanakaistataḥ || 41 ||
column2: 41. Tawny in colour and with quite heavy udders, the cow, in a contented mood, came very slowly floating over the waves.

column1: kāmadhenuṃ samāyāṃtīṃ dṛṣṭvā sarve surāsurāḥ | puṣpavarṣeṇa mahatā vavarṣuramitaprabhām || 42 ||
column2: 42. On seeing Kāmadhenu (Wish-yielding Cow) coming up, all Suras and Asuras showered flowers on that (cow) of unmeasured splendour.

column1: tadā tūryāṇyanekāni nedurvādyānyanekaśaḥ | ānītā jalamadhyācca saṃvṛtā gośatairapi || 43 ||
column2: 43. Various kinds of trumpets and musical instruments were played and drums were beaten. She was brought from the middle of the. waters (though) surrounded by hundreds of cows.

column1: tāsu nīlāśca kṛṣṇaśca kapilāśca kapiṃjalāḥ | babhravaḥ śyāmakā raktā jaṃbūvarṇāśca piṃgalāḥ | ābhiryuktā tadā gobhiḥ surabhiḥ pratyadṛśyata || 44 ||
column2: 44. Among them there were cows of various colours such as blue, black, tawny, partridge-coloured, smoke-coloured, dark-coloured, red ones, wooḍ-apple-coloured and reddish-brown ones. Surabhi was seen accompanied by these cows.

column1: asurāsurasaṃvītāṃ kāmadhenuṃ yayācire | ṛṣayo harṣasaṃyuktā devāndaityāṃśca tatkṣaṇāt || 45 ||
column2: 45. Sages who were delighted instantly entreated Devas and Asuras (to give to them) Kāmadhenu which was closely surrounded by them (Devas and Asuras).

column1: sarvebhyaścaiva viprebhyo nānāgotrebhya eva ca | surabhīsahitā gāvo dātavyā nātra saṃśayaḥ || 46 ||
column2: 46. “These cows aloṇg with Surabhi should be given to all Brāhmaṇas belonging to various Gotras. There is no doubt about it.”

column1: tairyācitāste'tra surāsurāśca daduśca tā gāḥ śivatoṣaṇāya | taiḥ svīkṛtāstā ṛṣibhiḥ sumaṃgalairmahātmabhiḥ puṇyatamaiḥ surabhyaḥ || 47 ||
column2: 47. On being requested by them, Suras and Asuras gave those cows to them in order to gratify Śiva. Those Surabhis (cows) were accepted by the noble-minded sages of great auspiciousness and excessive merit.

column1: puṇyāhaṃ munibhiḥ sarvaiḥ kāritāste tadā surāḥ | devānāṃ kāryasiddhyarthamasurāṇāṃ kṣayāya ca || 48 ||
column2: 48. Then Puṇyāhavācana[6] (the formal religious declaration ‘This is an auspicious day’) was performed for Suras by all those sages in order to enable Devas to achieve their objects and to cause the destruction of Asuras.

column1: punaḥ sarve susaṃrabdhā mamaṃthuḥ kṣīrasāgaram | mathyamānāttadā tasmādudadheśca tathā'bhavat || 49 || kalpavṛkṣaḥ pārijātaścūtaḥ saṃtānakastathā | tāndrumānekataḥ kṛtvā gandharvanagaropamān | mamaṃthurugraṃ tvaritāḥ punaḥ kṣīrārṇavaṃ budhā || 50 ||
column2: 49-50. All of them once again exerted themselves very well and churned the Milk Ocean. From the ocean that was being churned rose up Kalpavṛkṣa, Pārijāta, Cūta and Santānaka. They set apart those trees on one side, like the city of Gandharvas. Immediately those wise (Suras and Asuras) resumed the churning of the Milk Ocean powerfully in all earnestness.

column1: nirmathyamānādudadherabhavatsūryavarcasam | ratnānāmuttamaṃ ratnaṃ kaustubhākhyaṃ mahāprabham || 51 ||
column2: 51. From the ocean that was being churned emerged a highly refulgent, extremely bright, most excellent gem having the brilliance of the Sun. It was called Kaustubha.

column1: svakīyena prakāśena bhāsayaṃtaṃ jagattrayam | ciṃtāmaṇiṃ puraskṛtya kaustubhaṃ dadṛśurhi te || 52 || sarve surā dadustaṃ vai kaustubhaṃ viṣṇave tadā | ciṃtāmaṇi tataḥ kṛtvā madhye caiva surāsurāḥ | mamaṃthuḥ punarevābdhiṃ garjaṃtaste balotkaṭāḥ || 53 || mathyamānāttatastasmāduccaiḥśravāḥ samadbhutam | babhūva aśvo ratnānāṃ punaścairāvato gajaḥ || 54 ||
column2: 52-53. With its brilliance, it illuminated the three worlds. Keeping the Cintāmaṇi (a miraculous stone) in front, they saw the Kaustubha brightening the worlds. All those Suras gave the Kaustubha to Viṣṇu. Suras and Asuras of enhanced strength lustily roared again and began to churn the ocean keeping Cintāmaṇi in the middle.

column1: tathaiva gajaratnaṃ ca catuḥṣaṣṭyā samanvitam | gajānāṃ pāṃḍurāṇāṃ ca caturddantaṃ madānvitam || 55 || tānsarvānmadhyataḥ kṛtvā punaścaiva mamaṃthire | nirmathyamānādudadhernirgatāni bahūnyatha || 56 || madirā vijayā bhṛṃgī tathā laśunagṛṃjanāḥ | atīva unmādakaro dhattūraḥ puṣkarastathā || 57 ||
column2: 54-58. From the ocean that was being churned rose up Uccaiḥśravas, the wonderful gem of a horse, and then Airāvata, the gem of an elephant, along with sixty-four other white elephants each with four tusks and in the rut. They set apart all these in the middle and churned once again. Many precious things then arose from the ocean that was being churned, viz. the wine Vijayā, Bhṛṅgī, garlic, turnip, the poisonous and highly intoxicating Dhattūra (Datura Alba) which causes too much of madness, and Puṣkara. All these were placed on the shore of the ocean without any hurry. Again those great Asuras churned the ocean along with the excellent Suras.

column1: vadaṃti sarve kenasiddhāṃtayuktāṃ yāṃ yogamāyāṃ jñānaśaktyānvitā ye || 61 ||
column2: 59-61. As the ocean was being churned once again, that divine Lakṣmī,[7] the sole protector of the worlds, rose up from it. Those who are the knowers of Brahman call her Ānvīkṣikī (Metaphysics). Others praise her as Mūlavidyā. Some competent persons call her Brahmavidyā. Some call her Siddhi (Success), Ṛddhi (Prosperity), Ājñā (Command) and Āśā (Hope). Some Yogins call her Vaiṣṇavī. Some exponents of Māyā always engaged in Yogic practice call her Māyā. All people call her Kenasiddhāntayuktā (the one associated with Brahman—the Principle spoken of in the Kenopaniṣad). Those who are equipped with the power of knowledge call her Yogamāyā.

column1: nānāratnapradīpaiśca nīrājitamukhāṃbujām | cāruprasannavadanāṃ hāranūpūraśobhitām || 65 || mūrddhani dhriyamāṇena cchatreṇāpi virājitām | cāmarairvījyamānāṃ tāṃ gaṃgākallolalohitaiḥ || 66 || pāṃḍuraṃ gajamārūḍhāṃ stūyamānāṃ maharṣibhiḥ | suradrumapuṣpamālāṃ bibhratīṃ mallikāyutām || 67 ||
column2: 62-69. They saw Mahālakṣmī coming slowly. She was very fair, youthful and tender with the filaments of the lotus for her ornaments. She was sweetly smiling with beautiful teeth. A lady of slender shade, she had the fresh youthfulness as an adornment. Her garments and ornaments were variegated with the refulgence of many gems. Her lips were red like the Biṃba (Momordica monadelpha) fruits; the nose was very beautiful and the neck and the eyes were very splendid. She was very slender with fine waistline and splendid buttocks. The hips were large. Her lotus-like face was brilliantly illuminated by means of a number of gems that served the purpose of the lights in a Nīrājana rite for her face. Her face was fascinating and delightful. She was remarkably splendid with her necklaces and anklets. An umbrella was gorgeously held above her head. She was being fanned with chowries gently shaken by the waves of Gaṅgā. She was riding a white elephant and was being eulogized by great sages. With the ends of her hands, she held a garland of the flowers of heavenly trees along with jasmine flowers.

column1: karāgre dhriyamāṇāṃ tāṃ dṛṣṭvā devāḥ samutsukāḥ | ālokanaparā yāvattāvattāndadṛśe hyasau || 68 || devāṃśca dānavāṃścaiva siddhacāraṇapannagān | yathā mātā svaputrāṃśca mahālakṣmīstathā satī || 69 ||
column2: On seeing her Devas were eager to look at her at close quarters. But she, Mahālakṣmī, the chaste lady, looked at Devas, Dānavas, Siddhas, Cāraṇas and Serpents in the same manner as a mother looks (affectionately) at her children.

column1: ālokitāstathā devāstayā lakṣmyā śriyānvitāḥ | sañjātāstatkṣaṇādeva rājya lakṣaṇalakṣitāḥ | daityāste niḥśrikā jātā ye śriyā'navalokitāḥ || 70 ||
column2: 70. Devas were glanced at by that Lakṣmī. So they became prosperous instantaneously and were characterized by those indications of attainment of the kingdom. Daityas who were not glanced at by Lakṣmī became devoid of splendour (royal glory).

column1: nirīkṣyamāṇā ca tadā mukundaṃ tamālanīlaṃ sukapolanāsam | vibhrājamānaṃ vapuṣā pareṇa śrīvatsalakṣmaṃ sadayāvalokam || 71 ||
column2: 71-72. She glanced (lovingly) at Mukunda who was blue in complexion like Tamāla (Xanthochymus pictorius), whose cheeks and nose were very handsome, who shone brilliantly with his superior person and was characterized by Śrīvatsa and looked (at everyone mercifully).

column1: dṛṣṭvā tadaiva sahasā vanamālayānvitā lakṣmīrgajādavatatāra suvismayaṃtī | kaṃṭhe sasarja puruṣasya parasya viṣṇormālāṃ śriyā viracitāṃ bhramarairupetām || 72 ||
column2: On seeing him, Lakṣmī suddenly got down from her elephant with the garland of forest flowers (still in her hands). With a broad smile, she put round the neck of the Supreme Being Viṣṇu, the garland that was wreathed by Śrī herself and wherein bees swarmed together.

column1: vāmāṃgamāśritya tadā mahātmanaḥ sopāviśattatra samīkṣya tā ubhau | surāḥ sadaityā mudamāpuradbhutāṃ siddhāpsaraḥ kiṃnaracāraṇāśca || 73 ||
column2: 73. She then sat there leaning on the left side of the great Ātman. On seeing them both, Suras and Daityas experienced a wonderful joy. So also Siddhas, Apsarās (celestial damsels), Kinnaras and Cāraṇas.

column1: sarveṣāmeva lokānāmaikapadyena sarvaśaḥ | harṣo mahānabhūttatra lakṣmīnārāyaṇāgame || 74 || lakṣmyā vṛto mahāviṣṇurlakṣmīstenaiva saṃvṛtā | evaṃ parasparaṃ prītyā hyavalokanatatparau || 75 ||
column2: 74. At that union of Lakṣmī and Nārāyaṇa, the delight of everyone was very great. All the worlds, all the people everywhere were simultaneously happy and joyous. 75. Mahāviṣṇu was sought and wooed by Lakṣmī. Lakṣmī was wooed by him alone. Thus through mutual love they became absorbed in looking at each other.

column1: śaṃkhāśca paṭahāścaiva mṛdaṃgānakagomukhāḥ | bheryaśca jharjharīṇāṃ ca sa śabdastumulo'bhavat || 76 ||
column2: 76. The sound of the various musical instruments and drums sucḥ as Paṭahas, conchs, Mṛdaṅgas, Ānakas, Gomukhas, Bherīs and Jharjharīs was very tumultuous.

column1: babhūva gāyakānāṃ ca gāyanaṃ sumahattadā | tatāni vitatānyena ghānāni suṣirāṇi ca || 77 || evaṃ vādyaprabhedaiśca viṣṇuṃ sarvātmanā harim | atoṣayansugītajñā gaṃdharvāpsarasāṃ gaṇāḥ || 78 || tathā jagurnāradatuṃburādayo gaṃdharvayakṣāḥ surasiddha saṃghāḥ | saṃsevamānāḥ paramātmarūpaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ devamagādhabodham || 79 ||
column2: 77-79. The songs of the musicians were immensely splendid. With the four types of musical instruments, viz. Tata, Vitata, Ghana and Suṣira, the groups of Gandharvas and celestial damsels propitiated the all-pervading Lord Hari in every way. Gandharvas, being proficient in the art of music delighted the lord. Nārada, Tumburu and other Gandharvas and Yakṣas then sang sweetly. The groups of Suras and Siddhas served thus lord Nārāyaṇa who is in the form of the Supreme Ātman and whose enlightenment was boundless, deep and profound.

column1: iti śrīskāṃde mahāpurāṇa ekāśītisāhasryāṃ saṃhitāyāṃ prathame māheśvarakhaṇḍe kedārakhaṇḍe samudramanthanākhyāne lakṣmīprādurbhāvavarṇanaṃnāmaikādaśo'dhyāyaḥ || 11 ||
column2: Due to their negligence in worshipping Gaṇeśa, Asuras did not get the fruit (Ratnas—jewels) of their labour of churning the ocean.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | praṇamya paramātmānaṃ ramāyuktaṃ janārddanam | amṛtārthaṃ mamaṃthuste surāsuragaṇāḥ punaḥ || 1 ||
column2: Notes: This chapter describes how Asuras were cheated by Viṣṇu by assuming the form of an enchantress and were deprived of their share of Amṛta. Lomaśa said: 1. After bowing down to Janārdana, the Supreme Being, along with Ramā, the groups of Suras and Asuras once again churned the ocean for the sake of Nectar.

column1: udadhermathyamānācca nirgataḥ sumahāyaśāḥ | dhanvaṃtaririti khyāto yuvā mṛtyuñjayaḥ paraḥ || 2 ||
column2: 2. From the ocean that was being churned, came out a youthful person of very great fame, well-known as Dhanvantari.[1] He was the great conqueror of Mṛtyu (Death).

column1: pāṇibhyāṃ pūrṇakalaśaṃ sudhāyāḥ parigṛhya vai | yāvatsarve surāḥ sarve nirīkṣaṃte manoharam || 3 ||
column2: 3-4. He held in his hands a pot filled with nectar. While all Suras were (gladly) looking at the fascinating Lord Dhanvantari, Daityas wanted to attack him in a body and snatch away the pot (of nectar) that had been held in the hands of Dhanvantari.

column1: yāvattaraṃgamālābhirāvṛto'bhūdbhiṣaktamaḥ | śanaiḥ śanaiḥ samāyāto dṛṣṭo'sau vṛṣaparvaṇā || 5 ||
column2: 5. The excellent physician surrounded by a series of waves was advancing slowly when he was seen by Vṛṣaparvan.

column1: karasthaḥ kalaśastasya hṛtastena balādiva | asurāśca tataḥ sarve jagarjuratibhīṣaṇam || 6 ||
column2: 6. The pot that was in his hand was forcibly taken by him (Vṛṣaparvā). Thereupon, Asuras roared in a terrific manner.

column1: kalaśaṃ sudhayā pūrṇaṃ gṛhītvā te samutsukāḥ | daityāḥ pātālamājagmustadā devā bhramānvitāḥ || 7 ||
column2: 7. Seizing and taking the pot filled with nectar, the impatient Daityas came down to Pātāla. Then Devas became confused and embarrassed.

column1: anujagmuḥ susaṃnaddhā yoddhukāmāśca taiḥ saha | tadā devānsamālokya balirevamabhāṣata || 8 ||
column2: 8. They (Devas) who were well-prepared and ready for a battle, pursued them with a desire to fight. Turning towards Devas, Bali spoke thus:

column1: baliruvāca | vayaṃ tu kevalaṃ devāḥ sudhayā paritoṣitāḥ | śīghrameva pragaṃtavyaṃ bhavadbhiśca surottamaiḥ || 9 ||
column2: 9. O Devas, we are contented and gratified with the nectar only. You excellent Suras do go back quickly.

column1: triviṣṭapaṃ mudā yuktaiḥ kimasmābhiḥ prayojanam | purāsmābhiḥ kṛtaṃ maitraṃ bhavadbhiḥ svārthatatparaiḥ | adhunā viditaṃ tattu nātra kāryā vicāraṇā || 10 ||
column2: 10. Please go back to Triviṣṭapa (Heaven) joyously. Of what avail are we to you? Formerly we entered into a friendly alliance with you only because we wanted to realize our common objectives. Now it has been known to you. Do not have any doubt in it hereafter.

column1: evaṃ nirbhārtsitāstena balinā surasattamāḥ | yathāgatena mārgeṇa jagmurnārāyaṇaṃ prabhum || 11 ||
column2: 11. Thus rebuked and repulsed by Bali, those excellent Suras went back to Lord Nārāyaṇa along the path by which they had come.

column1: taṃ dṛṣṭvā viṣṇunā sarve surā bhagnamanorathā | āśvāsitā vacobhiśca nānānunayako vidaiḥ || 12 ||
column2: 12. On meeting him, all the Suras whose desires were frustrated, were consoled by Viṣṇu with various kinds of words capable of pacifying them:

column1: mā trāsaṃ kurutātrārtha ānayiṣyāmi tāṃ sudhām | evamābhāṣya bhagavānmukundo'nāthasaṃśrayaḥ || 13 || sthāpayitvā surānsarvāṃstatraiva madhusūdanaḥ | mohanīrūpamāsthāya daityanāmagrato'bhavat || 14 ||
column2: 13-14. “In this matter, do not be afraid unnecessarily. I shall bring back the nectar”, said Lord Viṣṇu, the refuge of those who are helpless. The slayer of Madhu (Viṣṇu) having asked all the Suras to stay there itself, assumed the form of a charming lady, Mohinī, and appeared before Daityas.

column1: tāvaddaityāḥ susaṃrabdhāḥ parasparamathābruvan | vivādaḥ sarvadaityānāmamṛtārthe tadā'bhavat || 15 ||
column2: 15. By that time Daityas had become highly excited and agitated. They spoke to one another (about this). For the sake of nectar, all the Daityas began arguing with one another.

column1: evaṃ pravartamāne tu mohinīrūpamāśritām | dṛṣṭvā yoṣāṃ tadā daivātsarvabhūtamanoramām || 16 || vismayena samāviṣṭā babhūvustṛṣitekṣaṇāḥ | tāṃ saṃmānya tadā daityarājo baliruvāca ha || 17 ||
column2: 16-17. While this was going on, fortunately they saw a woman fascinating the minds of all living beings (who had assumed the form of Mohinī). They were struck with wonder and with covetous eyes (they staled at her). Honouring her, Bali, the king of Daityas, said:

column1: baliruvāca | sudhā tvayā vibhaktavyā sarveṣāṃ gatihetave | śīghratvena mahābhāge kuruṣva vacanaṃ mama || 18 ||
column2: Bali said: 18. O highly fortunate lady, this nectar should be (properly) distributed by you, so that it can reach all. Be quick about it. Do as I request.

column1: evamuktā hyuvācedaṃ smayamānā baliṃ prati | strīṇāṃ naiva ca viśvāsaḥ kartavyo hi vipaścitā || 19 ||
column2: 19. On being requested thus, she smilingly said to Bali: “Women should never be trusted by a wise man.[2]

column1: anṛtaṃ sāhasaṃ māyā mūrkhatvamati lobhatā | aśaucaṃ nirghṛṇatvaṃ ca strīṇāṃ doṣāḥ svabhāvajāḥ || 20 ||
column2: 20. The following are the inherent natural defects of women: Falsehood, daring, deception, foolishness, excessive greed, uncleanliness and ruthlessness.

column1: niḥsnehatvaṃ ca vijñeyaṃ dhūrtatvaṃ caiva tattvataḥ | svastrīṇāṃ caiva vijñeyā doṣā nāstyatra saṃśayaḥ || 21 ||
column2: 21. Lack of genuine affection as well as mischievous cunningness should also be known as existing in them, in fact. These defects should undoubtedly be known as existing (even) in one’s own wives.

column1: yathaiva śvāpadānāṃ ca vṛkā hiṃsāparāyaṇāḥ | kākā yatāṃḍajānāṃ ca śvāpadānāṃ ca jaṃbukāḥ | dhūrtā tathā manuṣyāṇāṃ strījñeyā satataṃ budhaiḥ || 22 ||
column2: 22. Just as wolves among beasts of prey, crows among birds and foxes among wild animals are given to killing, so also women among human beings should always be understood by the wise as exceedingly mischievous and cunning.

column1: mayā saha bhavadbhiśca kathaṃ sakhyaṃ pravartate | sarvathātra na vijñeyāḥ ke yūyaṃ caiva ka hyaham || 23 ||
column2: 23. How can there be friendship and alliance between me and you all. Should this not be considered? Who are you and who am I?

column1: tasmādbhavadbhiḥ saṃciṃtyakāryākāryavicakṣaṇaiḥ | kartavyaṃ parayā buddhyā prayātāsurasattamāḥ || 24 ||
column2: 24. Hence everything should be done by you after careful consideration with your keen intellect. Of course, you are very efficient in knowing what should be done and what should not be done, O excellent Asuras.”

column1: baliruvāca | adyāmṛtaṃ ca sarveṣāṃ vibhajasva yathātatham | tvayā dattaṃ ca gṛhṇīmaḥ satyaṃsatyaṃ vadāmi te || 28 ||
column2: 27-29. “O lord, I shall follow your instructions whether they are good or bad.” Bali said: Today distribute the nectar among all in a befitting manner. We shall take what is given by you. It is true. I am speaking the truth.

column1: evamuktā tadā devī mohinī sarvamaṃgalā | uvācāthāsurānsarvānrocayaṃllaukikīṃ sthitim || 29 ||
column2: On being told thus, goddess Mohinī who was auspicious in every respect, spoke to all the Asuras desirous of following the conventional propriety: The Lord (i.e. Mohinī) said:

column1: bhagavānuvāca | yūyaṃ sarve kṛtārthāśca jātā daivena kenacit | adyopāvāsasaṃyuktā amṛtasyādhivāsanam || 30 || kriyatāmasurāḥ śreṣṭhāḥ śubhecchā kiṃcidasti vaḥ | śvebhūte pāraṇaṃ kuryādvratārcanaratiśca vaḥ || 31 || nyāyopārjitavittena daśamāṃśena dhīmatā | kartavyo viniyogaśca īśaprītyarthahetave || 32 ||
column2: 30-32. By a stroke of good luck, all of you have become blessed and achieved your desired objective, O excellent Asuras. Do observe fast today and let the preliminary consecratory rite of the nectar be performed. Something is yet (to be observed) with a desire for your welfare. Tomorrow you can have the Pāraṇā (ceremonial breakfast). Your desire for observances and worships (is commendable). For the sake of propitiating Īśa, the Viniyoga (ceremonious disposal) rite should be performed by an intelligent (devotee) with a tenth part of the amount legally and justifiably earned by him.

column1: tatheti matvā te sarve yathoktaṃ devamāyayā | cakrustathaiva daiteyā mohitā nātikovidāḥ || 33 ||
column2: 33. Saying “So be it”, they all honoured whatever was said by Devamāyā. Deluded and not being very proficient and experienced, they did everything advised by Devamāyā.

column1: mayāsureṇa ca tadā bhavanāni kṛtāni vai | manojñāni mahārhāṇi suprabhāṇi mahāṃti ca || 34 ||
column2: 34. Very big, fascinating, lustrous and rich mansions were built by the Asura, Maya.

column1: teṣupaviṣṭāste sarve susnātāḥ samalaṃkṛtāḥ | sthāpayitvā susaṃrabdhāḥ pūrṇaṃ kalaśamagrataḥ || 35 ||
column2: 35. They sat in those abodes after taking bath and adorning themselves befittingly. Excited much, they placed the full pot (of nectar) in front of themselves.

column1: rātrau jāgaraṇaṃ sarvaiḥ kṛtaṃ paramayā mudā | athoṣasi pravṛtte ca prātaḥsnānayutā bhavan || 36 ||
column2: 36. With very great joy, all of them kept vigil during the night. At dawn, they engaged themselves in taking early morning ablutions.

column1: asurā balimukhyāśca paṃktibhūtā yatākramam | sarvamāvaśyakaṃ kṛtvā tadā pānaratā bhavan || 37 ||
column2: 37. After finishing all necessary daily routine duties, Asuras, the chief of whom was Bali, sat in rows in due order. They were eager to drink (the nectar).

column1: baliśca vṛṣaparvā ca namuciḥ śaṃkha eva ca | sudaṃṣṭraścaiva saṃhlādī kālanemirvibhīṣaṇaḥ || 38 || vātāpirilvalaḥ kumbho nikumbhaḥ pracchadastathā | tathā sundopasundau ca niśumbhaḥ śumbha eva ca || 39 || mahiṣo mahiṣākṣaśca biḍālākṣaḥ pratāpavān | cikṣurākhyo mahābāhurjṛbhaṇo'tha vṛṣāsuraḥ || 40 ||
column2: 38-41. The following were the important ones among Daityas etc.: Bali, Vṛṣaparvan, Narauci, Śaṅkha, Sudaṃṣṭra, Saṃhlādī, Kālanemi, Vibhīṣaṇa, Vātāpi, Ilvala, Kuṃbha, Nikuṃbha, Pracchada, Sunda, Upasunda, Niśuṃbha, Śuṃbha, Mahiṣa, Mahiṣākṣa, the valorous Biḍālākṣa, the mighty-armed Cikṣura, Jṛṃbhaṇa, Vṛṣāsura, Vibāhu, Bāhuka, Ghora, Ghoradarśana, Rāhu and Ketu. These and many other Daityas, Dānavas and Rākṣasas sat there in due order.

column1: teṣāṃ tu koṭisaṃkhyānāṃ daityānāṃ paṃktirāsthitā || 42 || tatastayā tadā devyā amṛtārthaṃ hi vai dvijāḥ | yajjātaṃ tacchṛṇaudhvaṃ hi tayā devyā kṛtaṃ mahat || 43 ||
column2: 42-43. There were rows and rows of those Daityas numbering crores and crores. Now, O Brāhmaṇas, listen to what happened thereafter and what great things were done by that goddess in the matter regarding (the distribution of) the nectar.

column1: sarve vijñāpitāḥ sadyo gṛhītakalaśā tadā | śobhayā parayā yuktā sākṣātsā viṣṇumohinī || 44 || karasthena tadā devī kalaśena virājitā | śuśubhe parayā kāṃtyā jaganmaṃgalamaṃgalā || 45 ||
column2: 44-45. All were informed by her immediately (to be ready). She took up the pot. That Viśvumohinī was endowed with the greatest splendour. The goddess appeared splendid with the pot resting in her hands. The (goddess) conducive to the auspiciousness of all auspicious things in the universe shone with the greatest lustre.

column1: pariveṣadharāḥ sarve surāste hyasurāṃtikam | āgatāstatkṣaṇādeva yatra te hyasurottamāḥ || 46 ||
column2: 46. At the very same instant, all the Suras who had halos around them, came to the place where those excellent Asuras were present.

column1: tāndṛṣṭvā mohinī sadya uvāca pramadottamā || 47 ||
column2: 47. On seeing them, Mohinī, the most excellent one among young women, said immediately: Mohinī said:

column1: mohinyuvāca | ete hyatithayo jñeyā dharmmasarvasvasādhanāḥ | ebhyo deyaṃ yatāśaktyā yadi satyaṃ vaco mama | pramāṇaṃ bhavatāṃ cādya kurudhvaṃ mā vilaṃbatha || 48 ||
column2: 48. These (people) should be known as guests. They are conducive to the accomplishment of every thing virtuous. If you keep the promise given to me, something should be given to these in accordance with your capacity. You are the authority in this regard. Do everything now. Do not delay.

column1: pareṣāmupakāraṃ ca ye kurvaṃti svaśaktitaḥ | dhanyāste caiva vijñeyāḥ pavitrāḥ lokapālakāḥ || 49 ||
column2: 49. Those who render help to others in accordance with their capacity are blessed ones. They should be known to be very pure and protectors of the worlds.

column1: tasmādvibhajanaṃ kāryaṃ mayaitasya śubhavratāḥ | devebhyaśca prayacchadhvaṃ yaddhi cātmapriyāpriyam || 51 ||
column2: 50-51. Those who endeavour only for (filling in) their belly should be known as destined to suffer. There is no doubt about this. Hence, O (friends) of auspicious rites, this should be divided by me. You give Devas whatever you like or dislike.

column1: ityukte vacane devyā tathā cakrurataṃ dritāḥ | āhvayāmāsurasurāḥ sarvāndevānsavāsavān || 52 ||
column2: 52. When these words were spoken by the goddess, the energetic and alert Asuras did so. The Asuras invited all Devas including Vāsava.

column1: upaviṣṭāśca te sarve amṛtārthaṃ ca bho dvijāḥ | teṣūpaviśyamāneṣu hyuvāca paramaṃ vacaḥ | mohinī sarvadharmmajñā asurāṇāṃ smayanniva || 53 ||
column2: 53. All of them sat, O Brāhmaṇas, for the sake of receiving the nectar. While they were occupying their seats, Mohinī who was conversant with all holy rites and virtuous acts, smilingly said to the Asuras these great words:

column1: mohinyuvāca | ādau hyabhyāgatāḥ pūjyā iti vai vaidikī śrutiḥ || 54 ||
column2: Mohinī said:

column1: tasmādyūyaṃ vedaparāḥ sarve devaparāyaṇāḥ | bruvaṃtu tvaritenaiva ādau keṣāṃ dadāmyaham | amṛtaṃ hi mahābhāgā balimukhyā vadaṃtu bhoḥ || 55 ||
column2: 54-55. The Vedic Text prescribes that the guests should be honoured at the very outset. Hence, you who axe all devoted to the gods and the Vedas speak out immediately. So whom shall I give the nectar at the very outset? Indeed, let those whose leader is Bali, let those persons of exalted fortune say.

column1: balinoktā tadā devī yatte manasi rocate | svāminī tvaṃ na saṃdeho hyasmākaṃ suṃdarānane || 56 ||
column2: 56. Then the goddess was told by Bali. “(Do) what appeals to your mind. O lady of beautiful face, you are our mistress. There is no doubt about it.”

column1: evaṃ saṃmānitā tena balinā bhāvitātmanā | pariveṣaṇakāryārthaṃ kalaśaṃ gṛhya satvarā || 57 ||
column2: 57-58. On being honoured thus by that Bali of pure soul, the goddess hurriedly took up the pot for the purpose of serving.

column1: tasmānnarendrakarabhorulasaddṛkūlā śroṇītaṭālasagatirmavihvalāṃgī | sā kūjatī kanakanūpurasiṃjitena kuṃbhastanī kalaśapāṇirathāviveśa || 58 ||
column2: A silk cloth shone over her thighs resembling the trunk of a royal elephant. She walked rather slowly on account of the (huge) buttocks. Her limbs were agitated and excited due to inebriation. With the tinkling of the golden anklets, she appeared to be cooing (like a cuckoo). Her breasts resembled pitchers. With the pot (of nectar) in her hand, she entered (the place where they were seated).

column1: tadā tu devī pariveṣayaṃtī sā mohinī devagaṇāya sākṣāt | vavarṣa deveṣu sudhārasaṃ punaḥ punaḥ sudhāhārarasāmṛtaṃ yathā || 59 || punaśca te devagaṇāḥ sudhārasaṃ dattaṃ tayā parayā viśvamūrtyā | balimukhyāḥ saha lokapālā gaṃdharvayakṣāpsarasāṃ gaṇāśca || 60 ||
column2: 59-60. Then the goddess Mohinī proceeded serving the group of Devas directly. She showered on Devas the juice of the nectar again and again as though their sole diet consisted of this nectar. The groups of Devas, the chief among whom was Devendra, and the groups of Gandharvas, Yakṣas and celestial damsels along with Guardians of the Quarters swallowed again and again the juice of nectar served by that great (goddess) of cosmic form.

column1: sarve daityā āsanasthā punaśca te devagaṇāḥ sudhārasaṃ dattaṃ pīḍitāśca | tūṣṇīṃbhūtā balimukhyā dvijeṃdrā manasvino dhyānaparā babhūvuḥ || 61 ||
column2: 61. All Daityas, the chief among whom was Bali, O leading Brāhmaṇas, continued to be seated there. They were anxious and afflicted with hunger. The resolute Daityas kept quiet and were engaged in meditation.

column1: tatastathāvidhāndṛṣṭvā daityāṃstānmohamāśritān | tadā rāhuśca ketuśca dvāvetau daityapuṃgavau || 62 || devānāṃ rūpamāsthāya amṛtārthaṃ tvarānvitau | upaviṣṭau tadā paṅktyāṃ devānāmamṛtārthinau || 63 ||
column2: 62 -63. On seeing those Daityas in such a plight after resorting to a delusion, the two leading Daityas Rāhu and Ketu assumed the forms of Devas and hurriedly sat in the row of Devas for receiving the nectar.

column1: yadāmṛtaṃ pātukāmo rāhuḥ paramadurjayaḥ | candrārkābhyāṃ prakathito viṣṇoramitatejasaḥ || 64 || tadā tasya śiraśchinnaṃ rāhordurvigrahasya ca | śivaro gaganamāpede kabaṃdhaṃ ca mahītale | bhramamāṇaṃ tadā hyadrīṃścūrṇayāmāsa vai tadā || 65 ||
column2: 64-65. The exceedingly invincible Rāhu was desirous of drinking the nectar. When this was reported to Viṣṇu of unmeasured splendour by the Sun and the Moon, the head of Rāhu of deformed body was cut off. The head went up into the sky. The headless body dropped down on the earth. Rolling down, it crushed many mountains into small particles.

column1: sādriśca sarvabhūlokaścūrṇitaśca tadā'bhavat | tayā tena ca dehena cūrṇitaṃ sacarācaram || 66 || dṛṣṭvā tadā mahādevastasyopari tu saṃsthitaḥ | nivāsaḥ sarvadevānāṃ tasyāḥ pādatale'bhavat || 67 || pīḍanaṃ tatsamīpetha nivāsa iti nāma vai || 68 ||
column2: 66-68. The entire world including the mountains was reduced to fine dust. On seeing that the entire universe consisting of mobile and immobile beings was smashed to fragments by her (i.e. Mohinī) through that body (of Rāhu), Mahādeva stood above it. The abode of all Devas was at the soles of her feet. The affliction (?) was near her, hence the name Nivāsa[3] (abode) (obscure).

column1: mahatāmālayaṃ yasmādyasyāstaccaraṇāṃbujam | mahālayeti vikhyātā jagattrayavimohinī || 69 ||
column2: 69. Since her lotus-like feet had been the abode (ālaya) of great ones (mahatām), the enchantress of the three worlds became reputed as Mahālayā.

column1: ketuśca dhūmarūpo'sāvākāśe vilayaṃ gataḥ | sudhāṃ samarpya caṃdrāya tirodhānagato'bhavat || 70 ||
column2: 70. Ketu vanished into the sky in the form of smoke. It was after handing over the nectar to the Moon that he vanished thus.

column1: vāsudevo jagadyonirjagatāṃ kāraṇaṃ param | viṣṇoḥ prasādāttajjātaṃ surāṇāṃ kāryasiddhidam || 71 ||
column2: 71. Vāsudeva is the origin of the universe. He is the supreme cause of all the worlds. It was due to Viṣṇu’s grace that everything took place favouring the realization of Devas’ objectives.

column1: asurāṇāṃ vināśāya jātaṃ daivaviparyayāt | vinā daivena jānīdhvamudyamo hi nirarthakaḥ || 72 ||
column2: 72. Since the fate was adverse, the enterprise of Mohinī was conducive to the destruction of Asuras. Understand that all exertions without (favourable) fate are useless.

column1: yaugapadyena taiḥ sarvaiḥ kṣīrābdhermaṃthanaṃ kṛtam | siddhirjātā hi devānāmasiddhirasurānprati || 73 ||
column2: 73. The churning of the ocean was conducted by all of them simultaneously. But, it ended in the success of Devas, while Asuras failed (in their objective).

column1: tataśca te devavarānprakopitā daityāśca māyāpravi mohitāḥ punaḥ | anekaśastrāstrayutāstadā'bhavanviṣṇau gate garjamānāstadānīm || 74 ||
column2: 74. Therefore, they were furious at the excellent Devas. Daityas who were deluded took up many weapons and missiles. When Viṣṇu went away they began to roar. FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES: Dhanvantari: Mbh, Ādi 18.38 also states that Dhanvantari came out of ocean along with a pot of Amṛta. He is regarded as an incarnation of Viṣṇu. This divine physician Dhanvantari is different from Dhanvantari, the physician-king of Vārāṇasī. He learnt Āyurveda from sage Bharadvāja and composed a systematic work of eight parts on Āyurveda and taught it to different disciples (BdP II.3, 67.1-24).

column1: iti śrīskānde mahāpurāṇa ekāśītisāhasryāṃ saṃhitāyāṃ prathame māheśvarakhaṇḍe kedārakhaṃḍe samudramaṃthanākhyāne devānāmamṛtaprāśanavarṇanaṃnāma dvādaśo'dhyāyaḥ || 12 ||
column2: These traditional verses are meant for creating disaffection about Saṃsāra. Mohinī (Viṣṇu) cleverly uses them to create confidence about her in the gullible Asuras. The whole chapter shows how Mohinī cunningly appeals to the noble qualities of Asuras and cheats them.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | tataste garjjamānāśca ākṣipaṃtaḥ surānraṇe | śatakratupramukhyāṃstanmahābalaparākramān || 1 || vimānamāruhya tadā mahātmā vairocaniḥ sarvabalena sārddham | daityaiḥ sameto vividhairmahābalaiḥ surānpradudrāva mahābhayāvaham || 2 ||
column2: 1-2. Then (those Asuras) roared at the Suras, the chief among whom was Indra, and whose strength and valour was great. They challenged them for a fight. The noble-souled son of Virocana got into his aerial chariot. He was accompanied by Daityas who were very powerful and who came in various (groups). With his entire army he rushed at Suras in a terrible way.

column1: svāni rūpāṇi bibhraṃtaḥ samāpetuḥ sa hasraśaḥ | kecidvyāghrānsamārūḍhā mahiṣāṃśca tathā pare || 3 ||
column2: 3. They had assumed their (original real) forms. They attacked (the enemies) in thousands. Some of them rode on tigers and others on buffaloes.

column1: mayūrānrājahaṃsāṃśca kukkuṭāṃśca tathā pare | keciddhayānsamārūḍhā uṣṭrānaśvatarānapi || 5 || gajānkharānpare caiva śakaṭāṃśca tathā pare | pādātā bahavo daityāḥ khaṅgaśaktyṛṣṭipāṇayaḥ || 6 ||
column2: 4-6. Some of them rode on horses, others on elephants; while some others rode on lions, panthers and śarabhas (eight-footed mythical animal), peacocks, royal swans, cocks, horses, elephants, camels, mules and asses. Some drove in carts. Many Daityas came on foot with swords, javelins and daggers in their hands.

column1: parighāyudhinaḥ pāśaśūlamudgarapāṇayaḥ | asilomānvitāḥ kecidbhuśuṃḍīparighāyudhāḥ || 7 || hayanāgarathāścānye samārūḍhāḥ prahāriṇaḥ | vimānāni samārūḍhā balimukhyāḥ sahasraśaḥ || 8 ||
column2: 7-8. There were demons with iron bars as weapons. Others had nooses, javelins and iron clubs in their hands. Some had thin-bladed swords. Others had bhuṣuṇḍī (a sort of missile) and iron bolts as their weapons. Others came on horses, chariots and elephants and began to strike. Thousands of Asuras, the chief among whom was Bali, rode in aerial chariots.

column1: sparddhamānāstatānyonyaṃ garjaṃtaśca muhurmuhuḥ | vṛṣaparvā hyuvā cedaṃ balinaṃ daityapuṃgavam || 9 ||
column2: 9. They vied with one another roaring frequently. Vṛṣaparvan then said to Bali, the leading Daitya:

column1: tvayā kṛtaṃ mahābāho iṃdreṇa saha saṃgamam | viśvāso naiva kartavyo durhṛdā ca kathaṃcana || 10 ||
column2: 10. “O mighty one, an alliance was entered into with Indra by you. One should not place too much of faith in an evil-minded person.

column1: ūnenāpi hi tucchena vairiṇāpi kathaṃcana | maitrī buddhimatā kāryā āpadyapi nivartate || 11 ||
column2: 11-12. By no means should one trust and enter into an alliance with a base person, even if one happens to be weak and inferior. Friendship must be formed with an intelligent person. In case of emergency (he will help one) to make the mishap ineffective.

column1: na viśvasetpūrvavirodhinā kvacitparājitāḥ smo'tha bale tvayādhunā | purāṇaduṣṭāḥ kathamadya vai punarmaṃtraṃ vikartuṃ na ca te yateran || 12 ||
column2: One must not believe in a person who has been an enemy previously. It is because of you, O Bali, that we have been defeated now! Why should those chronic rogues not try to undo what has been agreed upon?”

column1: ityūcuste durādharṣā yoddhukāmā vyavasthitāḥ | dhvajaiśchatraiḥ patākaiśca raṇabhūmimamaṃḍayan || 13 ||
column2: 13. Those (sturdy Asuras) who could not be thwarted and were desirous of fighting said thus and arrayed themselves suitably. They adorned the battlefield with banners, umbrellas and flags.

column1: cāmaraiśca diśaḥ sarvā lopitaṃ ca raṇasthalam | tathā sarve surāstatra daityānprati samutsukāḥ || 14 ||
column2: 14-15. They covered all the quarters with chowries. The battlefield was completely covered up.

column1: pītvāmṛtaṃ mahābhāgā vāhānyāruhya daṃśitāḥ | gajārūḍho maheṃdropi vajrapāṇiḥ pratāpavān | sūryaścoccaiḥ śravārūḍho mṛgā rūḍhaśca candramāḥ || 15 ||
column2: Similarly all Suras were also eager to (fight with) Daityas. Those persons of exalted fortune drank the nactar, put on the coats of mail and got on their respective vehicles. Mahendra, the valorous one with vajra (thunderbolt) in his hand, rode on his elephant. The Sun was seated on Uccaiḥśravas and the Moon rode on a deer.

column1: chatracāmarasaṃvītāḥ śobhitā vijayaśriyā | praṇamya viṣṇuṃ te sarva iṃdrādyā jayakāṃkṣiṇaḥ || 16 ||
column2: 16. They were equipped with umbrellas and chowries. They were rendered splendid by the martial glory born of victory. Desirous of victory, all those persons beginning with Indra bowed down to Viṣṇu.

column1: te viṣṇunā hyanujñātā asurānprati vai ruṣā | asurāśca mahākāyā bhīmākṣā bhīmavikramāḥ || 17 || teṣāṃ boramabhūdyuddhaṃ devānāṃ dānavaiḥ saha | tumulaṃ ca mahāghoraṃ sarvabhūtabhayāvaham || 18 ||
column2: 17-18. Permitted by Viṣṇu, they angrily (rushed at) Asuras. Asuras of huge body, terrible eyes and dreadful exploits (withstood them). The fight of Devas with Dānavas was very terrible, tumultuous and exceedingly dreadful, instilling fear into all living beings.

column1: śaradhārānvitaṃ sarvaṃ babhūva paramādbhutam | tataśca ṭacaṭāśabdā babhūvuśca diśodaśa || 19 ||
column2: 19-20. Arrows were continuously showered. Everything became excessively wonderful. The rough and harsh noise like Caṭacaṭā reverberated in all the ten directions.

column1: tato nimiṣamātreṇa śaraghātayutā bhavan | śaratomaranārācairāhatāścāpatanbhuvi || 20 || vidhyamānāstathā kecidvividhuścāparānraṇe | bhallairbhagnāśca patitā nārācaiḥ śakalīkṛtāḥ || 21 ||
column2: Within a moment, they were wounded by arrows. Struck and hurt by arrows, iron clubs, javelins and iron-tipped missiles, they fell on the ground.

column1: kṣuraprahāritāḥ keciddaityā dānavarākṣasāḥ | śilīmukhairmāritāśca bhagnāḥ kecicca dānavāḥ || 22 ||
column2: 21-22. Even as they were being split and pierced, they split and tore others in the battle. They were shattered with Bhalla,1 arrows and smashed to pieces by Nārācas (iron-tipped arrows). Some of the Daityas, Dānavas and Rākṣasas were hit with many Kṣurapras (arrows with horseshoe-shaped tips) and they appeared to be torn with them. Some Dānavas were shattered and killed by Śilīmukhas (sharp-pointed arrows).

column1: evaṃ bhagnaṃ dānavānāṃ ca sainyaṃ dṛṣṭvā devā garjamānāḥ samaṃtāt | hṛṣṭāḥ sarve saṃmilitvā tadānīṃ labdhvā yuddhe te jayaṃ ślāghayante || 23 ||
column2: 23. On seeing the army of Dānavas broken up thus, Devas roared and moved all round. Delighted, they assembled together and celebrated the victory they had gained.

column1: śaṃkhavāditraghoṣeṇa pūritaṃ ca jagattrayam | devānprati kṛtāmarṣā dānavāste mahābalāḥ || 24 || baliprabhṛtayaḥ sarve saṃbhrameṇotthitāḥ punaḥ | vimānaiḥ sūryasaṃkāsairanekaiśca samanvitāḥ || 25 || dvaṃdvayuddhaṃ sutumulaṃ devānāṃ dānavaiḥ saha | saṃpravṛttaṃ punaścaiva parasparajigīṣayā || 26 ||
column2: 24-26. The three worlds were filled with the sounds of conchs and musical instruments. Dānavas of great strength became furious with Devas. Bali and all the others rose up once again with great excitement. They were equipped with many aerial chariots resembling the sun. With a desire to conquer each other Devas and Dānavas engaged themselves in tumultuous duels.

column1: balinā dānaveṃdreṇa maheṃdro yuyudhe tadā | tathā yamo mahābāhurnamucyā saha saṃgataḥ || 27 ||
column2: 27. Mahendra fought with Bali, the lord of Dānavas. Similarly, Yama of great and powerful arms met Namuci in combat.[1]

column1: nairṛtaḥ praghasenaiva pāśī kuṃbhena saṃgataḥ | nikuṃbhenaiva sumahadyuddhaṃ cakre sadārayaḥ || 28 ||
column2: 28. Nairṛta fought with Praghasa. Varuṇa clashed with Kuṃbha. Sadāraya (Wind-god) fought with Nikuṃbha.

column1: somena saha rāhuśca yuddhaṃ cakre sudāruṇam | rāhuṇā candradehotthamamṛtaṃ bhakṣitaṃ tadā | saṃparkādamṛsyaiva yathā rāhustathā'bhavat || 29 ||
column2: 29. Rāhu fought a very terrible combat with Soma (the Moon). The Amṛta (nectar) arising from the body of the Moon was imbibed by Rāhu. Due to the contact with nectar (another figure) like Rāhu rose up.

column1: tāni sarvāṇi dṛṣṭāni śaṃbhunā parameṣṭhinā | āśrayo'haṃ ca sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ nātra saṃśayaḥ | asurāṇāṃ surāṇāṃ ca sarveṣāmapi vallabhaḥ || 30 || evamuktastadā rāhuḥ praṇamya śirasā śivam | maulau sthitastadā caṃdro amṛtaṃ vyasṛjadbhayāt || 31 || tena tasya hi jātāni śirāṃsi subahūnyapi | ekapadyena teṣāṃ ca srajaṃ kṛtvā manoharām | babaṃdha śaṃbhuḥ śirasi śirobhūṣaṇavatkṛtam || 32 ||
column2: 30-32. All these things were seen by Śaṃbhu, the great lord. “There is no doubt about this that I am the base and support of all living beings. I am affectionate and dear to all, Asuras as well as Suras.” On being told thus Rāhu bowed down to Śiva. The Moon stationed on his crest discharged nectar out of fear. On account of it, many such heads were produced simultaneously. Śaṃbhu made them into a beautiful garland and tied it to his head like a (decorative) head-ornament.

column1: aśanātkālakūṭasya nīlakaṃṭho'bhavattadā | devānāṃ kāryasiddhyarthaṃ muṃḍamālā tathā kṛtā || 33 ||
column2: 33. By swallowing Kālakūṭa for the purpose of accomplishing the objective of Devas, he became blue-throated with a garland of skulls (thus) made.

column1: dadhāra śirasā tāṃ ca muṇḍamālāṃ maheśvaraḥ || 34 ||
column2: 34. Maheśvara wore the garland of skulls.

column1: tayā srajā'sau śuśubhe mahātmā devādidevastripurāṃtako haraḥ | gajāsuro yena nipātito mahānathāṃdhako yena kṛtaśca cūrṇaḥ || 35 ||
column2: 35. By means of that garland shone the noble-souled Hara, the primordial lord of Devas, the destroyer of Tripura. He is the lord by whom the great demon Gaja (Elephant) was struck down and the huge (demon) Andhaka was reduced to dust.

column1: gaṃgā dhṛtā yena śirassumadhye caṃdraṃ ca cūḍe kṛtavānbhayāpahaḥ | vedāḥ purāṇāni tathāgamāśca tathaiva nānāśrutayo'tha śāstram || 36 || jalpaṃti nānāgamabhedairmīmāṃsamānāśca bhavaṃti mūkāḥ | nānāgamārcāyamataprabhedairnirūpyamāṇo jagadekabaṃdhuḥ || 37 ||
column2: 36-37. It was Śiva by whom Gaṅgā was held in the middle of his head. He, the dispeller of fear, kept the Moon on his crest. Vedas, Purāṇas, Āgamas, different kinds of Śrutis and scriptures argue and discuss variously in accordance with difference in their respective texts. In the course of their discussion they become dumb. Śiva, the sole friend of the universe, is being investigated and described differently according to the opinion of the preceptors of different Āgamas.

column1: śivaṃ hi nityaṃ paramātmadaivaṃ vedaikavedyaṃ paramātmadivyam | vihāya taṃ mūḍhajanāḥ pramattāḥ śivaṃ na jānaṃti parātmarūpam || 38 ||
column2: 38. Abandoning the eternal lord Śiva, the supreme spirit that could be comprehended only through the Vedas, deluded people commit blunders. They do not realize Śiva of the form of the Great Spirit.

column1: yenaiva sṛṣṭaṃ vidhṛtaṃ ca yena yena śritaṃ yena kṛtaṃ samagram | yasyāṃśabhūtaṃ hi jagatkadācidvedāṃtavedyaḥ paramātmā śivaśca || 39 ||
column2: 39. Śiva is the Paramātmā (Supreme Soul) by whom everything is created and sustained. He pervades everything and evolves everything. The entire universe is a part of this Lord. He may, perhaps, be comprehended through the Vedānta.

column1: āḍhyo vāpi daridro vā uttamo hyadhamo'pi vā | śivabhaktirato nityaṃ śiva eva na saṃśayaḥ || 40 ||
column2: 40. A person always engaged in devotion to Śiva is undoubtedly Śiva, whether he is rich or poor, noble or base.

column1: yo vā parakṛtāṃ pūjāṃ śivasyopari śobhitām | dṛṣṭvā saṃtoṣamāyāti dāyaṃ prāpnoti tatsamam || 41 ||
column2: 41. If a person becomes delighted on seeing the splendid worship of Śiva performed by others, he gets a gift (i.e. merit) equal to his (i.e. that of the worshipper).

column1: ye dīpamālāṃ kurvaṃti kārtikyāṃ śraddhayānvitāḥ | yāvatkālaṃ prajvalaṃti dīpāste liṃgamagrataḥ | tāvadyugasahasrāṇi dātā svarge mahīyate || 42 ||
column2: 42. People should offer rows of lamps in the month of Kārttika with great faith. A devotee who offers lamps thus is honoured in heaven for as many thousands of Yugas as the number (of hours) during which those lamps burn in front of the Liṅga.[2]

column1: kausuṃbhatailasaṃyuktā dīpā dattāḥ śivālaye | dātāraste'pi kailāse modante śivasaṃnidhau || 43 ||
column2: 43. If the lamps with safflower oil are offered in the temple of Śiva, those who offer them rejoice in Kailāsa in the presence of Śiva.

column1: atasītailasaṃyuktā dīpā dattāḥ śivālaye | te śivaṃ yāṃti saṃyuktāḥ kulānāṃ ca śatena vai || 44 ||
column2: 44. If the lamps with linseed oil are offered in the temple of Śiva, those who offer them rejoice in Kailāsa in the presence of Śiva.

column1: jñānino'pi hi jāyaṃte dīpadānaphalena hi || 45 ||
column2: 45-46. As a result of the offering of lamps, people become Jñānins (endowed with perfect knowledge).

column1: tilatailena saṃyuktā dīpā dattāḥ śivālaye | te śivaṃ yāṃti saṃyuktāḥ kulānāṃ ca śatena vai || 46 ||
column2: If the lamps with gingelly oil are offered in the temple of Śiva, they (the offerers) go to Śiva in the company of a hundred members of their family.

column1: ghṛtāktā yaiḥ kṛtā dīpā dīpitāśca śivālaye | te yāṃti paramaṃ sthānaṃ kulalakṣasamanvitāḥ || 47 ||
column2: 47. Those by whom lamps are filled with ghee and lit in the temple of Śiva, go to the highest abode in the company of a hundred thousand members of own family.

column1: karpūrāgurudhūpaiśca ye yajaṃti sadā śivam | ārārtikāṃ sakarppūrāṃ ye kurvaṃti dinedine | te prāpnuvaṃti sāyujyaṃ nātra kāryā vicāraṇā || 48 ||
column2: 48. Those who worship Śiva always with camphor, aloe and incense and those who perform the rite of waving lights everyday along with camphor, attain Sāyujya (identity with the Divinity). There is no doubt about it.

column1: ekakālaṃ dvikālaṃ vā trikālaṃ ye hyataṃdritāḥ | liṃgārcanaṃ prakurvaṃti te rudrā nātra saṃśayaḥ || 49 ||
column2: 49. Those who worship the Liṅga once, twice or thrice a day with care are Rudras (themselves). There is no doubt about it.

column1: rudrākṣadhāraṇaṃ ye ca kurvaṃti śivapūjane | dāne tapasi tīrthe ca parvakāle hyataṃdritāḥ | teṣāṃ yatsukṛtaṃ sarvamanaṃtaṃ bhavati dvijāḥ || 50 ||
column2: 50. If the devotees wear Rudrākṣa beads[3] at the time of the worship of Śiva, when charitable gifts are offered, when penance is performed, in the holy spots and during festive occasions with care, their merit is infinite, O Brāhmaṇas.

column1: rudrākṣā ye śivenoktāstācchṛṇudhvaṃ dvijottamāḥ | ārambhaikamukhaṃ tāvadyābadvaktrāṇi ṣoḍaśa | eteṣāṃ dvau ca vijñeyau śreṣṭhau tārayituṃ dvijāḥ || 51 ||
column2: 51. Listen, O excellent Brāhmaṇas, to what Śiva has said about Rudrākṣa beads. There are Rudrākṣas with one face, two faces etc. up to sixteen faces- Among these, two should be known as the most excellent ones. O Brāhmaṇas, which redeem (devotees).

column1: rudrākṣāṇāṃ paṃcamukhakhastathā caikamukhaḥ smṛtaḥ | ye dhārayaṃtyekamukhaṃ rudrākṣamaniśaṃ narāḥ | rudralokaṃ ca gacchaṃti modante rudrasaṃnidhau || 52 ||
column2: 52. They are the five-faced Rudrākṣa and the single-faced Rudrākṣa. Those men who always wear the single-faced Rudrākṣa, go to the world of Rudra and rejoice in the presence of Rudra.

column1: japastapaḥ kriyā yogaḥ snānaṃ dānārcanādikam | kriyate yacchṛbhaṃ karmma hyanaṃtaṃ cākṣadhāraṇāt || 53 ||
column2: 53. Japa, penance, holy rites, yogic practice, holy bath, charitable gift, worship etc.—if these splendid rites are performed while wearing Rudrākṣa beads, these rites yield infinite results.

column1: śunaḥ kaṃṭhanibaddho'pi rudrākṣo yadi vartate | so'pi saṃtāritastena nātra kāryā vicāraṇā || 54 ||
column2: 54. If a Rudrākṣa bead is tied round the neck of even a dog, it will be redeemed thereby. There is no doubt about it.

column1: tathā rudrākṣasaṃbaṃdhātpāpamapikṣayaṃ vrajet | evaṃ jñātvā śubhaṃ karma kāryaṃ rudrākṣabaṃdhanāt || 55 ||
column2: 55. Due to the association of the Rudrākṣa bead one’s sin will be destroyed. Knowing this one should perform auspicious rites after wearing a Rudrākṣa bead.

column1: tripuṇḍradhāraṇaṃ yeṣāṃ vibhūtvā mantrapūtayā | te rudraloke rudrāśca bhaviṣyaṃti na saṃśayaḥ || 56 ||
column2: 56. If the devotees have Tripuṇḍra (three horizontal parallel lines on the forehead) (marked) with Vibhūti (sacred ash) sanctified by Mantras, they will undoubtedly become Rudras and (rejoice) in the world of Rudra.

column1: kapilāyāśca saṃgṛhya gomayaṃ cāṃtarikṣagam | śuṣkaṃ kṛtvātha saṃdāhyaṃ vibhūtyarthaṃ śivapriyaiḥ || 57 ||
column2: 57. The dung of a tawny-coloured cow should be gathered before it touches the ground. It must be dried and burned by the devotees of Śiva for preparing Vibhūti.

column1: vibhūtīti samākhyātā sarvapāpapraṇāśinī | lalāṭeṃ'guṣṭharekhā ca ādau bhāvyā prayatnataḥ || 58 || madhyamāṃ varjayitvā tu aṃgulīkdvayena ca | evaṃ trirekhāsaṃyukto lalāṭe yasya dṛśyate | sa śaivaḥ śivavajjñeyo darśanātpāpanāśanaḥ || 59 ||
column2: 58-59. It is called Vibhūti. It destroys all sins. At the outset, a single line should be drawn carefully with the thumb on the forehead. Then, two lines should be drawn, one above and one below the previous line by means of two fingers avoiding the middle finger. If the three lines are clearly visible on the forehead, that person is a devotee of Śiva. He should be known as the destroyer of sins by (his) mere sight, like Śiva.

column1: jaṭādharāśca ye śaivāḥ sapta paṃca tathā nava | jaṭā ye sthāpiyiṣyaṃti śaivena vidhinā yutāḥ || 60 || te śivaṃ prāpnuvaṃ tīha nātra kāryā vicāraṇā | rudrākṣadhāraṇaṃ kāryaṃ śivabhaktairviśeṣataḥ || 61 ||
column2: 60-61. Those devotees of Śiva who keep matted hair, keep five, seven or nine such clusters. Those who do so in accordance with the injunctions in Śaiva treatises, do attain Śiva. There is no doubt about this. Rudrākṣa beads should be worn particularly by Śiva’s devotees.

column1: alpena vā mahattvena pūjito vā sadāśivaḥ | kulakoṭiṃ samuddhṛtya śivena saha modate || 62 ||
column2: 62. Sadāśiva can be worshipped with a very little quantity (of materials) or with profusely rich material. The devotee redeems thereby ten million members of his family and rejoices with Śiva.

column1: tasmācchivātparataraṃ nāsti kiṃciddvijottamāḥ | yadaivamucyate śāstre tatsarvaṃ śivakāraṇam || 63 ||
column2: 63. Hence, O excellent Brāhmaṇas, there is nothing greater than Śiva. When this is told in the scripture (it must be known that), everything has Śiva for its cause.

column1: śivo dātā hi lokānāṃ kartā caivānumoditā | śivaśaktyātmakaṃ viśvaṃ jānīdhvaṃ hi dvijottamāḥ || 64 ||
column2: 64. Indeed Śiva is the bestower of the worlds. He is the maker of the worlds. He rejoices along with (his devotees). Know, O excellent Brāhmaṇas, that the whole universe consists of both Śiva and Śakti.

column1: śiveti dvyakṣaraṃ nāma trāyate mahato bhayāt | tasmācchivaściṃtyatāṃ vai smaryatāṃ ca dvijottamāḥ || 65 ||
column2: 65. The two-syllabled name Śi-va saves one from very great danger. Hence, O excellent Brāhmaṇas, let Śiva be contemplated upon and remembered. The sages said:

column1: ṛṣaya ūcuḥ | somanāthasya māhātmyaṃ jñātaṃ tasya prasādataḥ | rāhoḥ śirobhayātsarve rakṣitāḥ parameṣṭhinā || 66 || surāśceṃdrādayaścānye tasminyuddhe sudāruṇe | ata ūrdhvaṃ surāḥ sarve kimakurvata ucyatām || 67 || śivasya mahimā sarvaḥ śrutastava mukhodgataḥ | atha yuddhasya vṛttāntaḥ kathyatāṃ paramārthataḥ || 68 ||
column2: 66-68. The greatness of Somanātha has been understood. It was due to his grace that all were saved from the fear of the heads of Rāhu by Parameṣṭhin. Suras beginning with Indra and others (were saved by the lord) in that dreadful battle. Thereafter, what did all those Suras do? Let it be narrated. Everything about the greatness of Śiva as narrated by you was heard directly (while) uttered by you orally. Let the narration of the battle be made exactly as it happened.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | yadā hi daityaiśca parājitāḥ surāḥ śambhuṃ ca sarve śaraṇaṃ prapannāḥ | śivaṃ praṇemuḥ sahasā surottamā yuddhāya sarve ca mano dadhustadā || 69 ||
column2: Lomaśa said: 69. When Suras were defeated by Daityas, all of them sought refuge in Śaṃbhu. The excellent Suras bowed down to Śiva. All of them immediately decided to fight.

column1: tathaiva daityā api yudhyamānā utsāhayuktātibalāśca sarve | devaiḥ sametāśca punaḥ punaśca yuddhaṃ pracakruḥ paramāstrayuktāḥ || 70 ||
column2: 70. Similarly, all Daityas who were very powerful and enthusiastic began to fight. Equipped with great missiles, they came into contact with Devas and fought again and again.

column1: evaṃ ca sarve hyasurāḥ surāśca śaktyṛṣṭiśūlaiḥ parighaiḥ paraśvadhaiḥ | jayārthinomarṣayutāḥ parasparaṃ siṃhā yathā haimavatīṃ durātyayāḥ | nihanyamānā hyasurāḥ suraistadā nānāstrayogaiḥ paramairnipetuḥ || 71 ||
column2: 71. Thus, all Suras and Asuras who were desirous of victory and who were exceedingly furious, fought with one another with javelins, swords, spears, iron bars and axes. Being struck down and hit by Suras with many great arrows and missiles combined with one another Asuras (though) indomitable fell down in the same manner as lions falling into Gaṅgā.

column1: cakruste sakalāmurvī māṃsaśoṇitakardamām | mahīṃ vṛkṣādrisaṃyuktāṃ sasāgaravanākarām || 72 ||
column2: 72. They made the entire earth muddy with flesh and blood. They made the entire earth including oceans, forests, mines, trees and mountains (full of blood and flesh).

column1: śirāṃsi ca kabandhāni kavacāni mahāṃti ca | dhvajārathāḥ patākāśca gajavājiśirāṃsi ca || 73 ||
column2: 73. Deep rivers of blood lashed and swept heads, headless bodies, great armours, flags, chariots, banners and heads of elephants and horses.

column1: bahantyaścāpagā hyāsannadyo bhīrubhayāvahāḥ | agādhāḥ śoṇitodāśca taraṃto brahmarākṣasāḥ | tayaṃti parānbhūtapratapramatharākṣasān || 74 ||
column2: 74. These rivers instilled fear into the minds of cowards. Brahmarākṣasas crossed these bloody rivers and made the other goblins, ghosts, Pramathas and Rākṣasas cross them.

column1: śākinīḍākinīsaṃghā yakṣiṇyo'tha sahasraśaḥ | nānākeliṣu saṃyuktāḥ parasparamudānvitāḥ || 75 ||
column2: 75. There were groups of female devils such as Śākinīs, Ḍākinīs etc. and thousands of Yakṣiṇīs. Rejoicing in the company of each other, they were engaged in various sports.

column1: evaṃ saṃkrīḍamānāste bhūtapramatharākṣasāḥ | raṇe tasminmahāraudre devāsurasamāgame || 76 ||
column2: 76. Thus, in that highly dreadful battle Devas and Asuras clashed directly with one another. There Bhūtas, Pramathas and Rākṣasas continued their sports.

column1: balinā saha devendro yuyudhe'dbhutavikramaḥ | śaktyā jaghāna deveṃdraṃ vairocaniramarṣaṇaḥ || 77 ||
column2: 77. Devendra of wonderful exploits fought with Bali. The infuriated son of Virocana (Bali) struck Devendra with a javelin.

column1: tāṃ śaktiṃ vañcayāmāsa mahendro laghuvikramaḥ | jaghāna sa baliṃ yatnāddaityeṃdraṃ parameṇa hi || 78 || vajreṇa śitadhāreṇa bāhuṃ ciccheda vikramī | gātāsurapatadbhūmau vimānātsūryasaṃnnibhāt || 79 ||
column2: 78-79. Mahendra of quick and nimble steps dodged that javelin. He struck Bali, the lord of Daityas, with great effort and force with his great thunderbolt of sharp edges The valorous (lord of Devas) cut off his (Bali’s) arms. (Thereupon) he fell down dead on the ground from his aerial chariot resembling the sun.

column1: patitaṃ ca baliṃ dṛṣṭvā vṛṣaparvā rūpānvitaḥ | vavarṣa śaradhārābhiḥ payoda iva parvatam || 80 || maheṃdraṃ sagajaṃ caiva sahamānaṃ śitāñcharān | tadā yuddhamabhūdvoraṃ mahendravṛṣaparvaṇoḥ || 81 || nipātya vṛṣaparvāṇamiṃdraḥ parabalārdanaḥ || 82 ||
column2: 80-81. On seeing Bali fallen, Vṛṣaparvan furiously showered Mahendra and his elephant with a volley of arrows like the cloud showering a mountain. Mahendra bore the sharp arrows. Then a terrible battle ensued between Mahendra and Vṛṣaparvan.

column1: tato vajreṇa mahatā dānavānavadhīdraṇe | śirasi ccheditāḥ kecitkecitkaṃdharato hatāḥ || 83 || vihvalāśca kṛtāḥ kecidiṃdreṇa kupitena ca | tathā yamena nihatā vāyunā varuṇena ca || 84 || kubereṇa hatāścānye nairṛtena tathā pare | agninā nihatāḥ kecidīśenaiva vidāritāḥ || 85 ||
column2: 82-85. Indra, the tormentor of the enemy’s army, caused Vṛṣaparvan to fall down. Then he killed Dānavas in the battle with his great thunderbolt. Some were pierced through the head. Some were hit in the neck. Some were rendered bewildered and afflicted by the furious Indra. Similarly, Dānavas were killed by Yama, Vayu and Varuṇa. Others were killed by Kubera and Nairṭta. Some were killed by Agni and torn asunder by Īśa

column1: evaṃ tadā tairnihatā balīyaso mahāsurā vikramaśāninaśca | suraistu sarvaiḥ saha lokapālaiḥ śivaprasādā bhihatāstadānīm || 86 ||
column2: 86. Thus the powerful Asuras of great exploit were killed by Suras and the guardians of the worlds. It was due to the favour of Śiva that they were killed then.

column1: tato mahādaityavaro durātmā sa kalānemiḥ paramāstrayuktaḥ | yayau tadānīṃ surasattamāṃstānhaṃtuṃ sadā krūramatiḥ sa ekaḥ || 87 ||
column2: 87. Then the great and excellent Daitya who was equipped with excellent missiles and weapons came in to kill the excellent Suras. The evil-minded demon who was very cruel in his heart advanced alone.

column1: siṃhārūḍho daṃśitaśca triśulena hi saṃyutaḥ | daityānāmarbudenaiva siṃhārūḍhena saṃvṛtaḥ || 88 ||
column2: 88. Armoured and armed with a trident, he rode on a lion surrounded by one hundred millions of Daityas, all riding on lions.

column1: te siṃhā daṃśitāḥ sarve mahābalaparākramāḥ | teṣu siṃheṣu cārūḍhā mahādaityāśca tatsamāḥ || 89 ||
column2: 89. All those lions of great strength and exploit were equipped with coats of mail. The great Daityas riding on those lions were also equal to them.

column1: āyāṃtīṃ daityasenāṃ tāṃ sarvāṃ siṃhavibhūṣitām | kālanemiyutāṃ dṛṣṭvā devā iṃdrapurogamāḥ | bhayamājagmuratulaṃ tadā dhyānaparā bhavan || 90 ||
column2: 90. On seeing the entire army of Daityas, that was adorned by lions and led by Kālanemi, advancing, the Devas with Indra, their leader, became exceedingly frightened. Then they began to ponder.

column1: kiṃ kurmo'dya vayaṃ sarve kathaṃ jeṣyāma cādbhutam | etādṛśamasaṃkhyākamanīkaṃ siṃhasaṃvṛtam || 91 ||
column2: 91. ‘What shall we all do now? How will we conquer this wonderful and countless army surrounded by lions?’

column1: evaṃ viciṃtyamānāste hyāgatastatra nāradaḥ | nāradena ca tatsarvaṃ purāvṛttaṃ mahattaram || 92 || kathitaṃ ca maheṃdrāya kālanemestapobalam | ajeyatvaṃ ca saṃgrāme varadānabalena tu || 93 ||
column2: 92-93. When they were thinking thus, Nārada happened to come there. The old story of Kālanemi’s power of penance was told to Mahendra by Nārada. He told him about his invincibility in battle, by virtue of the power of boons granted to him.

column1: viṣṇuṃ vinā vayaṃ devā aśaktā raṇamaṃḍale | jetuṃ ca sa tato viṣṇuḥ smaryatāṃ parameśvaraḥ | tamālanīlo varadaḥ sarvairvijayakāṃkṣibhiḥ || 94 ||
column2: 94. “O Devas, we are not competent to conquer (this army) in the battle ground without Viṣṇu’s help. Hence, let the great lord Viṣṇu, the lord dark in complexion like the Tamāla leaves, the bestower of boons, be remembered by (all of you) desirous of conquest.”

column1: nāradasya vacaḥ śrutvā tadā devāstvarānvitāḥ | dhyānena ca mahāviṣṇuṃ tataḥ parabalārddanam | smaraṃtaḥ paramātmānamidamūcuśca taṃ vibhum || 95 ||
column2: 95. On hearing the words of Nārada, Devas hurriedly meditated on Mahāviṣṇu, the tormentor of the enemy’s army, the Supreme Soul. Remembering the lord, they prayed to him thus: Devas said:

column1: devā ūcuḥ | namastubhyaṃ bhagavate namaste viśvamaṃgalam | śrīnivāsa namastubhyaṃ śrīpate te namonamaḥ || 96 ||
column2: 96. Obeisance to you, the lord, the cause of the auspiciousness of the universe. O Śrīnivāsa (Abode of Śrī), obeisance to you. O Śrīpati (Consort of Goddess Lakṣmī), obeisance, obeisance to you.

column1: adyāsmānbhayabhītāṃstvaṃ kālanemibhayārditān | trātumarhasi daityācca devānāmabhayaprada || 97 ||
column2: 97. Today we are exceedingly frightened. We are oppressed by the fear of Kālanemi. It behoves you, O lord, the bestower of freedom from fear to Devas, to save us from the Daitya.

column1: evaṃ dhyātaḥ saṃsmṛtaśca prādurbhūto haristadā | nīlo garuḍamāruhya jagatāmabhayapradaḥ || 98 ||
column2: 98. On being meditated and remembered thus, the dark-complexioned Hari, the bestower of freedom from fear to all the worlds, appeared before them riding on Garuḍa.

column1: cakrapāṇistadāyāto devānāṃ vijayāya ca | gaganasthaṃ mahāviṣṇuṃ garuḍopari saṃsthitam | śrīvāsamenaṃ durddharṣaṃ yoddhukāmaṃ dadarśire || 99 ||
column2: 99. The lord with the discus in his hand came there for the victory of Devas. They all saw Mahāviṣṇu seated on Garuḍa and stationed in the firmament, the invincible lord Śrīvāsa (the resort of Śrī) who was desirous of fighting.

column1: tathā dṛṣṭvā kālanemistadānīṃ prahasyamāno'tiruṣā balānvitaḥ | kastvaṃ mahābhāga vareṇyarūpaḥ śyāmo yuvā vāraṇamattavikramaḥ | kare gṛhītaṃ niśitaṃ mahāprabhaṃ cakraṃ ca kasmātkathayasva me prabho || 100 ||
column2: 100. On seeing the lord like that, Kālanemi who was very mighty and highly infuriated, said laughingly (loudly): “Who are you, O exalted one of great fortune? You are excellent in form and features. You are young and dark-complexioned and possess the valour of an elephant in rut. A sharp-edged brilliant discus is held by you in your hand. Why? Let me know, O Lord.”

column1: śrībhagavānuvāca | yuddhārthamiha cāyāto devānāṃ kāryasiddhaye | tvaṃ sthiro bhava re maṃda dahāmyadya na saṃśayaḥ || 101 ||
column2: The Lord said: 101. I came here for the purpose of fighting, for the fulfilment of the cause of Devas. Be steady, O stupid one, I shall undoubtedly burn you now.

column1: śrutvā bhagavato vākyaṃ kālanemiḥ pratāpavān | uvāca ruṣito bhūtvā bhagavaṃtamadhokṣajam || 102 ||
column2: 102. On hearing the words of the Lord, the valorous Kālanemi became angry and said to lord Adhokṣaja (Viṣṇu):

column1: mūlabhūto hi devānāṃ bhagavānyuddhadurmadaḥ | yuddhaṃ kuru mayā sārddhaṃ yadi śūro'si saṃprati || 103 ||
column2: 103. “You are the lord and root-cause of Devas. You are highly proud of your ability to fight. If you are a brave warrior, fight with me now.”

column1: prahasya bhagavānviṣṇuruvācedaṃ mahāprabhaḥ | gaganastho bhava tvaṃ hi mahīstho'haṃ bhavāmi vai || 104 || apraśastaṃ ca viṣamaṃ yuddhaṃ caiva yathā bhavet | tathā kuru mahābāho gagano vā mahītale || 105 ||
column2: 104-107. Lord Mahāviṣṇu of great lustre laughed and said: “Either you be stationed in the sky, or I shall be stationed on the earth. O mighty one, fight either in the sky or on the ground, so that the battle will not be on uneven planes and blameworthy.”

column1: tatheti matvā hi mahānubhāvo daityaiḥ sameto'rbudasaṃkhyakaiśca | siṃhoparisthaiśca mahānubhāvairmahābalaiḥ krūrataraistadānīm || 106 || gaganamatha jagāhe maṃdamaṃdaṃ mahātmā hyasuragaṇasameto viśvarūpaṃ jighāṃsuḥ | triśikhamaparamugraṃ gṛhya saṃdeśaceṣṭādaśanavikṛtavaktro yoddhukāmo hariṃ saḥ || 107 ||
column2: Saying “So be it” the Daitya of great mangificence, surrounded by one hundred million Daityas who were dignified and glorious and seated on lions, who were powerful and ruthless, rose up in the sky slowly. He was accompanied by the groups of Asuras. He was desirous of killing (Viṣṇu) the lord of cosmic form. He took up another fierce trident with a desire to fight with Hari. His mouth and face had a hideous form due to his (curved ferocious) teeth as well as (his desire to send) an oral message (to his followers).

column1: iti śrīskāṃde mahāpurāṇa ekāśītisāhasryāṃ saṃhitāyāṃ prathame māheśvarakhaṇḍe samudramaṃthanākhyāne devāsurasaṃgrāmavarṇanaṃnāma trayodaśo'dhyāyaḥ || 13 ||
column2: Rudrākṣa is the ‘berry’ of Elaeocarpus ganitrus. It is of different kinds, ‘one-faced’, ‘five-faced’ etc. Genuine ‘one-faced’ Rudrākṣa is rare and is valued highly. VV 50-55 describe the spiritual importance of wearing Rudrākṣa.[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available]

column1: lomaśa uvāca | tato yuddhamatīvāsīdasurairviṣṇunā saha | tataḥ siṃhāḥ sapakṣāste daṃśitāḥ paramādbhutāḥ || 1 || asurairuhyamānāste rahutmaṃtaṃ vyadārayan | siṃhāste dāritāstena khaṃḍaśaśca vidāritāḥ || 2 ||
column2: 1-2. Then the fight between Asuras and Viṣṇu became exceedingly terrific. The exceedingly wonderful winged lions equipped with armours and ridden by Asuras tore up Garuḍa. The lions too were pierced and torn to pieces by him.

column1: viṣṇunā ca tadā daityāścakreṇa śakalīkṛtāḥ | hatāṃstānasurāndṛṣṭvā kālanemiḥ pratāpavān || 3 || triśūlenāhanadviṣṇuṃ roṣaparyākulekṣaṇaḥ | tamāyāṃtaṃ ca jagṛhe mukuṃdo'nāthasaṃśrayaḥ || 4 ||
column2: 3-4. Then Daityas were cut into pieces by Viṣṇu with his discus. On seeing Asuras killed, the valorous Kālanemi, with his eyes full of wrath, struck Viṣṇu with his trident. Mukunda (Viṣṇu), the support of those who are helpless, caught hold of the trident as it rushed at him.

column1: kareṇa vāmena jaghāna līlayā taṃ kālanemiṃ hyasuraṃ mahābalam | tenaiva śūlena samāhato'sau mūrcchānvito'sau sahasā papāta || 5 ||
column2: 5. Viṣṇu playfully caught hold of Kālanemi, the Asura of great power with his trident, by his left hand sportively. Being struck with the self-same trident, he suddenly fell down senseless.

column1: patitaḥ punarutthāya śanairunmīlya locane | purataḥ sthitamālokya viṣṇuṃ sarvaguhāśayam || 6 ||
column2: 6-7. The fallen Daitya came to senses again and slowly opened his eyes. Regaining consciousness, he saw Yiṣṇu standing in front of him—Viṣṇu, the lord abiding in the cavity of the heart of everyone. Kālanemi of great strength then spoke these words:

column1: labdhasaṃjño'bravīdvākyaṃ kālanemirmahābalaḥ | tava yuddhaṃ na dāsyāmi nāsti loke spṛhā mama || 7 ||
column2: “I will not offer to fight with you, I have no desire for worlds (and worldly pleasures).

column1: ye ye'surā hatā yuddhe akṣayaṃ lokamāpnuyuḥ | brahmaṇo vacanātsadya iṃdreṇa saha saṃgatāḥ || 8 || bhuṃjato vividhānbhogāndevavadvicaraṃti te | iṃdreṇa sahitāḥ sarve saṃsāre ca pataṃtyatha || 9 ||
column2: 8-9. According to the words of Brahmā, those Asuras who are killed in the battle will attain the Akṣaya (Everlasting) world. Immediately they will come into contact with Indra. Enjoying various kinds of worldly pleasures, they will roam about like gods along with Indra. Then they will fall down to the earthly world.

column1: tasmādyuddhena maraṇaṃ na kāṃkṣe kṣaṇabhaṃguram | anyajanmani me vīra vairabhāvānna saṃśayaḥ | dātumarhasi me nātha kaivalyaṃ kevalaṃ param || 10 ||
column2: 10. Hence, I do not desire death in battle. It is of a momentary nature. O heroic lord, it behoves you to grant me Kaivalya (salvation) alone, the great benefit, in the course of my next birth, of course, as a result of an inimical attitude.”

column1: tatheti daityapravaro nipātitaḥ pareṇa puṃsā paramārthadena | dattvā'bhayaṃ devatānāṃ tadānīṃ tathā sudhāṃ devatābhyaḥ pradattvā || 11 ||
column2: 11. Saying “So be it”, the Supreme Being, the bestower of the greatest benefit, caused the excellent Daitya to fall down. Having given Sudhā (nectar) to Devas (before) and having granted freedom from fear to Devas (now) (the lord saved them).

column1: kālanemirhato daityo devā jātā hyakaṭakāḥ | śalyarūpo mahānsadyo viṣṇunā prabhaviṣṇunā || 12 ||
column2: 12. Kālanemi, the great Daitya who was like a dart, was killed by Viṣṇu, the powerful lord. Devas became rid of thorns (enemies). 13-14. The lotus-eyed Lord vanished immediately.

column1: tirodhānaṃ gataḥ sadyo bhagavānkamalekṣaṇaḥ | iṃdro'pi kadanaṃ kṛtvā daityānāṃ paramādbhutam || 13 || patitānāṃ klībarūpāṇāṃ bhagnānāṃ bhītacetasām | muktakacchaśikhānāṃ ca cakre sa kadanakriyām || 14 ||
column2: Having caused extremely wonderful (terrific) havoc among Daityas, Indra also continued the slaughter of Daityas who were fallen, cowardly like eunuchs, broken (in spirit) and frightened in mind, and had their garments and tufts of hair loosened.

column1: arthaśāstraparo bhūtvā maheṃdro durātikramaḥ | daityānāṃ kālarūpo'sau śacīpatirudāradhīḥ || 15 ||
column2: 15. The liberal-minded consort of Śacī (Indra), who was like the god of Death unto Daityas and who could never be conquered (did all these things), because, he was devotedly following the (instructions laid down in the) Arthaśāstra.[1]

column1: evaṃ nihanymānānāmasurāṇāṃ śacīpateḥ | nivāraṇārthaṃ bhagavānāgato nāradastadā || 16 ||
column2: 16. While Asuras were being killed like this, the holy lord Nārada came there in order to make Indra desist from it.

column1: nārada uvāca | yuddhahatāśca ye vīrā hyasurā raṇamaṇḍale | teṣāmanu kathaṃ kartā bhītānāṃ ca vihiṃsanam || 17 ||
column2: Nārada said: 17. Many heroic Asuras have been killed fighting in the battlefield. Why do you kill the frightened ones after that?

column1: ye bhītāṃśca prapannāṃścaghātayaṃti madoddhatāḥ | brahmaghnāste'pi vijñeyā mahāpātakasaṃyutāḥ || 18 ||
column2: 18. The haughty and arrogant ones who cause the death of those who are afraid and those who seek refuge should be known as murderers of Brāhmaṇas. They are guilty of great sins.

column1: tasmāttvayā na karttavyaṃ manasāpi vihiṃsanam | evamuktastadā śakro nāradena mahātmanā || 19 || surasenānvitaḥ sadya āgato hi triviṣṭapam | tadā sarve suragaṇāḥ suhṛdbhyaśca parasparam | babhūvurmuditāḥ sarve yakṣagaṃdharvakiṃnarāḥ || 20 ||
column2: 19-20. Hence, even mentally injury should not be caused by you. On being told thus by the noble-souled Nārada, Indra immediately came back to Triviṣṭapa (heaven) accompanied by the armies of Suras. Then all the groups of Suras, all the Yakṣas, Gandharvas and Kinnaras became joyous. Along with their friends, they enjoyed the company of one another.

column1: tadā iṃdro'marāvatyāṃ hasa śacyā'bhiṣecitaḥ || 21 || devarṣipramukhaiścaiva brahmarṣipramukhaistathā | śakro'pi vijayaṃ prāptaḥ prasādācchaṃkarasya ca || 22 ||
column2: 21-26a. Then Indra was crowned in Amarāvatī along with Śacī by leading celestial sages and leading Brāhmaṇa sages. It was due to the favour of Śaṅkara that Śakra attained victory.

column1: tadā mahotsavo viprā devaloke mahānabhūt | śaṃkhāśca paṭahāścaiva mṛdaṃgā murajā api | tathānakāśca bheryaśca nedurduṃdubhayaḥ samam || 23 || gāyakāścaiva gaṃdharvāḥ kinnarāścāpsapogaṇāḥ | nanṛturjagustuṣṭuvuśca siddhacāraṇaguhyakāḥ || 24 ||
column2: Then, O Brāhmaṇas, there was a great celebration in the world of Devas. Then conchs and different kinds of drums like Paṭahas, Mṛdaṅgas, Murajas, Ānakas, Bherīs and Dundubhis were sounded simultaneously. Gandharvas and Kinnaras were the musicians. The groups of celestial damsels danced. Siddhas, Cāraṇas and Guhyakas sang praises.

column1: evaṃ vijayamāpannaḥ śakro devesvarastadā | devairhatāstadā daityāḥ patitāste mahītale || 25 ||
column2: Thus Śakra, the lord of Devas, attained victory. 26b-27a. At that time, the noble-souled Daityas, the chief among whom was Bali and who had been killed by Devas, fell down lifeless on the surface of the earth.

column1: gatāsavo mahātmāno balipramukhato hyamī | tapastaptuṃ purā vipro bhārgavo mānasottaram || 26 ||
column2: Formerly the Brāhmaṇa Bhārgava (accompanied by his disciples) had gone to mount Mānasottara for performing penance. Hence he was not aware of that battle.

column1: gataḥ śiṣyaiḥ parivṛtastasmādyuddhaṃ na veda tat | avaśeṣāśca ye daityāste gatā bhārgavaṃ prati || 27 || kathitaṃ vai mahaddhṛttamasurāṇāṃ kṣayāvaham | niśamya manyumāviṣṭo hyāgato bhṛgunaṃdanaḥ || 28 || śiṣyaiḥ parivṛto bhūtvā mṛtāṃstānasurānapi | vidyayā mṛtajīvinyā patitānsamajīvayat || 29 ||
column2: 27b-29. Those Daityas who had survived approached Bhārgava. The news of the great destruction of Asuras was conveyed to him. On hearing it, the son of Bhṛgu became furious. He returned surrounded by his disciples. With the Vidyā (magic formula) called Mṛtajīvinī (‘Resuscitator of the dead’), he revived the Asuras who had fallen dead.

column1: nidrāpāyagatā yadvadutthitāste tadā'surāḥ | utthitaḥ sa baliḥ prāha bhārgavaṃ hyamitadyutim || 30 ||
column2: 30. Then those Asuras got up as though they had awakened from sleep. Bali who rose up, said to Bhārgava of unmeasured splendour:

column1: jīvitena kimadyaiva mama nāsti prayojanam | pātitastridaśeṃdreṇa yathā kāpuruṣastathā || 31 ||
column2: 31. “Of what avail is it to me today to be revived back to life? There is no benefit to me. I have been struck down by the lord of Devas like a mean contemptible wretch.”

column1: balinoktaṃ vacaḥ śrutvā śukro vacanamabravīt | manasvino hi ye śūrāḥ pataṃti samare budhā || 32 || ye śastreṇa hatāḥ sadyo mriyamāṇā vrajaṃti vai | triviṣṭapaṃ na saṃdeha iti vedānuśāsanam || 33 ||
column2: 32-33. On hearing the words uttered by Bali, Śukra spoke these words: “Those heroic persons who are high-souled and intelligent, who are learned, and who fall down dead in battle on being struck by a weapon go to heaven. This is undoubtedly the statement of the Vedas.”

column1: evamāśvāsayāmāsa balinaṃ bhṛgunaṃdanaḥ | tapastatāpa vividhaṃ daityānāṃ siddhidāyakam || 34 ||
column2: 34. Thus, the son of Bhṛgu consoled Bali. He then performed various kinds of penance conducive to the achievement of Siddhis by Daityas.

column1: tathā daitya gatāḥ sarve bhṛguṇā ca pracoditāḥ | pātālamavasansarve balimukhyāḥ sukhena vai || 35 ||
column2: 35. All the Daityas urged by Bhṛgu went to Pātāla. All the Daityas, the chief among whom was Bali, stayed in Pātāla in happiness. FOOTNOTES AND REFERENCES: Arthaśāstra—A treatise on political economy. It is the title of a famous work of Kauṭilya or Ārya Cāṇakya who masterminded the revolution in Pāṭalīputra (Magadha), uprooted the Nanda dynasty and installed Candragupta Maurya as the King. Kauṭilya refers to many predecessors. Hence the Arthaśāstra mentioned here may be a more ancient work than that of Kauṭilya.[Sanskrit text for this chapter is available]

column1: | ṛṣaya ūcuḥ | rājyaṃ prāpto hi deveṃdraḥ kathitaste guruṃ vinā | guroravajñayā jāto rājyabhraṃśo hi tasya tu || 1 || kena praṇoditaśceṃdro babhūva ciramāsane | tatsarvaṃ kathayāśu tvaṃ paraṃ kautūhalaṃ hi naḥ || 2 ||
column2: The sages enquired: 1-2. It has been mentioned by you that Devendra regained kingdom without his preceptor. It was on account of disrespect to his preceptor that he had been dethroned from his kingdom. Urged by whom did he retain his position for a long time? Do tell us all these things quickly. We are very eager to hear it.

column1: lomaśa uvāca | guruṇāpi vinā rājyaṃ kṛtavānsa śacīpatiḥ | viśvarūpoktavidhinā iṃdro rājye sthito mahān || 3 ||
column2: Lomaśa replied: 3-4. The consort of Śacī (Indra) ruled over the kingdom (of heaven) without his preceptor (Bṛhaspati). The great Indra (could) continue (to rule) over the kingdom due to the (religious) performance in accordance with the injunctions of Viśvarūpa.

column1: viśvakarmasuto viprā viśvarūpo mahānṛpaḥ | purohito'tha śakrasya yājakaścābhavattadā || 4 ||
column2: 5-6. O Brāhmaṇas, Viśvarūpa,[1] a great king, was the son of Viśvakarmā. He became the preceptor and performer of sacrifices for Śakra.

column1: tasminyajñe'vadānaiśca yajane asurānsurān | manuṣyāṃścaiva triśirā aparokṣaṃ śacīpateḥ || 5 ||
column2: In that Yajña, Triśiras (one with three heads) performed the worship with partial oblations separately for Asuras, Suras and human beings.

column1: devāndadāti sākrośaṃ daityāṃstūṣṇīmathādadāt | manuṣyānmadhyapātena pratyahaṃ sa grahāndvijaḥ || 6 ||
column2: In the direct presence of Indra everyday he used to give ladles (full of Soma) to Devas with a loud shout, to Daityas silently, and to human being in a fallen middle tone.

column1: ekadā tu maheṃdreṇa sūcito gurulāghavāt | alakṣyamāṇena tadā jñātaṃ tasya cikīrṣitam || 7 ||
column2: 7-8. Once he was detected due to his partiality (regarding relative importance of oblations) by Indra who remained concealed and unobserved. Then the desired object (of Triśiras) was understood (by Indra).

column1: daityānāṃ kāryasiddhyarthamavadānaṃ prayacchati | asau purohito'smākaṃ pareṣāṃ ca phalapradaḥ || 8 ||
column2: (Deveṇdra thought) ‘He is making this piecemeal offering for the sake of accomplishing the task of Daityas. He is our preceptor, but gives the benefit to (our) enemies.’

column1: iti matvā tadā śakro vajreṇa śataparvaṇā | ciccheda tacchirāṃsyeva tatkṣaṇādabhavadvadhaḥ || 9 ||
column2: 9. After thinking thus, Śakra cut off his heads instantaneously by means of his Vajra (thunderbolt) of hundred spikes. The death was instantaneous.

column1: yenākarotsomapānamajāyaṃta kapiṃjalāḥ | tatonyena surāpānātkalaviṃkā bhavanmukhāt || 10 || anyānanādajāyaṃta tittirā viśvarūpiṇaḥ | evaṃ hato viśvarūpaḥ śakreṇa maṃdabhāginā || 11 ||
column2: 10-11. The Kapiñjala (a sort of partridge) birds were born from the face with which he drank Soma juice. Then from the other face with which-he drank liquor, the Kalaviṅka (sparrow) birds were born. From the other (third) face, the Tittira birds of various forms were born. Thus, Viśvarūpa was killed by Śakra, the ill-fated one.

column1: brahmahatyā tadodbhūtā durdharṣā ca bhayāvahā | durdharṣā durmukhā duṣṭā caṇḍālarajasānvitā || 12 ||
column2: 12-14. The female fiend (born of and called) Brahmahatyā (‘Brāhmaṇa-murder’) manifested there. She was terrific and unthwartable. She was evil-faced, wicked, full of Cāṇḍāla impurity and could not be blocked or defeated.

column1: brahmahatyā surāpānaṃ steyaṃ gurvaṃganāgamaḥ | ityeṣāmapyaghavatāmidameva ca niṣkṛtiḥ || 13 ||
column2: The terrible sinners are those who slay Brāhmaṇas, those who drink liquor, those who steal (gold etc.) and those who defile and outrage the modesty of the preceptor’s wife. The means of expiation for these sinners is the utterance of the names of Viṣṇu, since the mind has him for its object.

column1: nāmavyāharaṇaṃ viṣṇoryatastadviṣayā matiḥ | triśirā dhūmrahastā sā śakraṃ grastumupāyayau || 14 ||
column2: The three-headed fiend with smoke-coloured hands rushed forth to swallow Indra.

column1: tato bhayena mahatā palāyanaparo'bhavat | palāyamānaṃ taṃ dṛṣṭvā hyanuyātā bhayāvahā || 15 ||
column2: 15. Thereupon (Indra) fled from there out of great fear. On seeing him fleeing, the terrible (devil) chased him.

column1: yato dhāvati sā'dhāvattiṣṭhaṃtamanutiṣṭhati | aṃgakṛtā yathā chāyā śakrasyapariveṣṭitum | āyāti tāvatsahasā iṃdro'pyapsu nyamajjata || 16 || śīghratvena yathā viprāściraṃtanajalecaraḥ || 17 ||
